movie_review_blurb: Playing with genre expectations as much as jumping around in time to instil dread and disquiet, it's a very compelling and skilfully well-made chiller, but a brutally violent watch many may find cruelly uncomfortable.
Apart from the odd effective sequence, this is nothing but a by-the-numbers survival story peddling contrived emotion, glittering sets and repetitive CGI peril.
Joffé's interest clearly lies in society's obsession with celebrity rather than the nuances of the genre, but Cohen's precision script succeeds in keeping him on the terror track.
Tthis ingenious satirical comedy drama about media omnipotence is both dazzling and sophisticated from audacious start to poignant finale.
The duo, clearly so comfortable in their characters' skin, indulge in intelligent banter, sharp humour and emotional truths.
Unapologetic and hard-hitting, Irvine Welsh's controversial bestseller is brought to the screen as a dazzling assault on the senses.
Linda Hamilton turns in another terrific performance as the fiercely committed heroine who puts a necessary human face on Cameron's high-decibel mayhem and pyrotechnical bravura.
John Williams's Oscar-winning music and the excellent performances of Roy Scheider and Richard Dreyfuss add to the ingeniously mounted tension that cleverly plays on all our deepest primeval fears.
Pure adrenaline-pumping entertainment of the highest order.

This inventive nail-biter is very much a product of its time -- blending the arms-race unease of the early 1980s with the beginning of the home-computer revolution -- but it still manages to both grip and entertain.
Surpassing its predecessor in terms of sheer spectacle, this sequel to Ridley Scott's outer-space nightmare from director James Cameron is an outstanding science-fiction thriller.
Great special effects, inventive alien designs and Smith and Jones's hip, hilarious double act make director Barry Sonnenfeld's Lethal Weapon-style buddy picture a fast-paced pleasure.
Leonard Nimoy has rarely been so moving.
movie_title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)

movie_review_blurb: High adventure and vertigo blend with blood and bullets to make this tension-packed tall tale a spectacular avalanche of dizzying escapism.
Nothing is overplayed, from the scary surveillance tracking methods to the high-level corruption, making this a superbly crafted masterclass in intelligent action film-making.
George Clooney and Jennifer Lopez sizzle in this sexy, sly and snappy crime caper from director Steven Soderbergh, that neatly combines its 1970s heist-picture roots with sparkling romantic comedy.
It's a long but entertainingly showy melodrama full of cineaste jokes, tricksy wordplay and references to film-makers GW Pabst, Leni Riefenstahl and Sergio Leone.

Director Irvin Kershner's imaginative supervision of George Lucas's brainchild gives this second part of the first Star Wars trilogy a truly epic dimension, adding a mature, philosophical aspect to the nonstop barrage of brilliant special effects.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Hold on tight, because it starts at full throttle and never lets up.
In an exemplary piece of casting, Downey Jr gives a powerhouse performance, adding depth and believability to his character as both self-indulgent waster and do-gooder superhero.
If any movie musical could threaten the standing of retro favourite Grease, it's this one.

Endlessly imitated but never rivalled, this opening instalment of George Lucas's original space trilogy dresses up the timeless tale of good versus evil with ground-breaking special effects and a dazzling array of intergalactic characters.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Too much creeping around and a lack of genuine creepiness doom this tepidly spooky experience.
Genuinely striking and unnerving, the film manages to ramp up the fright factor to such overly intense levels that uneasy laughter provides the only release.
A haunting, touching and visually sublime reinvention of undead mythology.
Not so much moving as stomach churning.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Bigger in scope than the original, the film's nonstop mayhem includes cartoonish battles, geysers of CGI blood and seemingly impossible stunts, with the geriatric gang of beloved icons placed centre stage for maximum thrills.
There's much to enjoy here ...
A dazzling curio in which every sound effect reverberates with multiple meanings.
This is brisk and brutal film-making.
A total mess that strains for poetic meaning. Yet it also has enough hypnotic power to carry one's attention through even the clumsiest and obvious passages.

Cool in its crafty mood placement, confidently restrained during its nastiest moments and mining provocative lines of devastating nuance, the movie reaches a terrifying crescendo as the grisly Super 8 reels bleed into high-pitched scares.
The ultimate message about ignorance being the scariest thing of all is a sincere one, but it gets lost in the nonstop, eager-to-please, uninspired zaniness.
It's beautifully shot, handsomely mounted and well cast ...
Doors creak, shadows flicker, cats jump: the laziest sequel yet in the supernatural franchise barely bothers to change the formula at all.
[A] simple but horribly effective low-budget suburban horror ...

This wonderful Warner Bros version of Ted Hughes's The Iron Man is a first-class achievement in cartoon virtuosity that liberally borrows images from 1950s comic-book art and science-fiction movies to stunning effect.
A model feel-good movie that sparkles with heartfelt humour ...
Destined to become definitive holiday entertainment for all the family.
A one-note pastiche featuring impressive wire-fu, bloody mayhem and CGI mutilation.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The on-screen fireworks were reportedly fuelled by off-screen hatred, but the chemistry between the stars is unquestionably hair-raising and upped the Gothic stakes to camp shock levels.
movie_title: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)

movie_review_blurb: This ambitious mix of mirth and menace is an offbeat and hugely enjoyable affair.
[A] visceral and deeply moving true story ...
This dark fable is a subversive stomach-churner and not for the faint-hearted.
A colourfully cute romp for kids.
[A] fast and furious all-action continuation of the classic fairy tale ...

This is, at best, dull escapism but there are a few reasons to keep watching, including Stanley Tucci camping away as the hissable villain and knight Ewan McGregor being sausage-rolled up by a chef colossus.
This dumb ramble isn't a patch on the original.
Indecently funny, delightfully eccentric and far bloodier than you'd expect ...
Only Cronenberg can get away with working out his raw phobias on screen while being poignantly witty and repulsively entertaining at the same time.
This skilfully directed psychodrama from Christopher Nolan proves that hit European movies can be remade successfully.

This masterfully sleek vision of the future from director Steven Spielberg is an awesome mix of skewed science fiction, twisty Hitchcock-style thrills, stunning blue-grey tinged photography and outstanding design.
Director Sam Raimi burst onto the horror scene with this crude cult favourite that's short on story but long on excessive gore and innovative camerawork.
Director George A Romero redefined the meaning of horror for fear-sated audiences in the 1960s with this seminal classic.
Even in the dark, it's clear where this is going -- but Wan does know his way around a haunted house.
The magnum opus of Vincent Price's film career, this stylish, witty comedy horror boasts an irresistible premise, an inspired ensemble cast, fabulous music and first-rate production values.
movie_title: Theater of Blood (Theatre of Blood) (Much Ado About Murder) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Compelling, creepy and often unbearably tense.
Bram Stoker's terrifying vampire creation becomes a modern classic in the adept hands of the House of Hammer.
A top-flight terror classic that spawned seven sequels and a TV series.
[A] glorious-looking slice of gothic horror, which also helped establish Vincent Price as a horror icon.

Cynical, devastating and relentless, director George A Romero's gruelling masterpiece about the American Dream turning into a terrifying nightmare is a brilliant blend of black comedy and hip, if harrowing, carnage.
Although expertly remade twice - in 1978 and 1993 - and rather less successfully in 2007, the original is still the most striking, with a justly famous scalp-freezing ending.
Campbell mugs shamelessly and clearly has a ball as scene outdoes scene in comic thrust and haphazard horror.
It's one of the most powerful films ever made about Devil worship because Polanski expertly winds up the paranoia with spooky atmospherics and morbid humour.
Christopher Lee, who plays the lord of the island, thinks it's one of the finest films he's ever made -- and he's right.
In this highly sophisticated and disturbing Canadian horror movie, director John Fawcett transcends the banality of the werewolf formula with verve, well-paced action and genuine terror.
This is one of the best supernatural chillers ever made.
It's slick, glossy and engaging, if nowhere near as clever as zom-com Shaun of the Dead.
Thematically complex, yet intelligently integrating eastern philosophy, Lewis Carroll and ancient mysticism.

The search for the Holy Grail and the final battle are simply stunning sequences, and, while the dizzying pace leaves scant time for proper characterisation, Nicol Williamson, Nigel Terry and Helen Mirren make their mark.
One of Hollywood's quintessential productions, this musical adaptation of L Frank Baum's classic fable is probably the most beloved fantasy film of all time and the ultimate family picture.
It's an opulent odyssey that balances romance, comedy and thrills in one glittering and constantly surprising package.
Peter Jackson deservedly won the best director Oscar for this powerful and enchanting concluding episode to his massively ambitious adaptation of JRR Tolkien's trilogy.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This beautifully designed, cherry blossom-hued cartoon is brighter, breezier and bouncier than most.
Amiably retro in its icky shock value, this love story with an alien twist is often so funny it's scary.
A nimble and well-crafted chase thriller.
Time has not dimmed the shock value of this seminal classic from director Tobe Hooper that's based on the same real-life case that inspired Psycho.

Shocking in its day and still a genuinely creepy experience, director James Whale's primitive yet enthralling interpretation of Mary Shelley's classic tale of man playing God is the most influential genre movie ever made.
Director John Landis here pulls off the difficult trick of revitalising the horror genre while parodying it at the same time.
Despite outdated acting techniques and staging, this is a must-see for all cinema buffs, as make-up genius Lon Chaney's Phantom is a Hall of Horror landmark.
Count Orlock, played by the hideous Max Schreck, creeps through Murnau's archetypal silent imagery with a mesmerising authority that retains a surprising amount of tension.
movie_title: Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (Nosferatu the Vampire) (1922)

movie_review_blurb: If it's gratuitous Saxon violence you're after then you've come to the right place.

Hooper's direction may lack its usual edgy personality -- apparently over-ruled by Spielberg's script suggestions -- but he puts on a dazzling show, and the intuitive performances are uniformly on the panic button.
A stunning combination of menacing Grand Guignol atmosphere, dazzling colours, gory violence, lush décor and pounding soundtrack.
This most enduring adaptation of the Faustian moral fable is totally satisfying.
James Whale's extravagantly produced sequel to his own Frankenstein still ranks as one of horrordom's greatest achievements.
This revolutionary "haunted house in space" thrill-ride is the classic business, stunning you with shock after shock, even when the fascinating monster is exposed in all its hideous glory.
Super-scary and vicious, both psychologically and physically, this cleverly produced chill-ride is edgy British horror at its very best.
It remains the most subtly romantic and highly atmospheric rendition of Bram Stoker's tale about the Transylvanian count, with Browning orchestrating the opening scenes to macabre perfection.
The lighting, shadows, exotic setting and music all contribute to the immensely disturbing atmosphere, making this stunning piece of poetic horror a classic of the genre.

If you like Pegg and director Edgar Wright's cult Channel 4 series Spaced, you'll enjoy this deadpan blend of undergraduate humour and hardcore horror, which ransacks George A Romero's Dead saga and virtually every Italian zombie flick for inspiration.
Brian De Palma's modern gothic fairy tale, based on Stephen King's bestseller, offers a tense and lyrical web of emotions.
[An] engrossing yet strangely unembellished adaptation of Stephen King's bestseller by director David Cronenberg.

The thrilling finale is a terrific blend of heartfelt emotion, surreal visuals and inventive ghostly spectacle, and the film's timeless message is put across in wonderfully ghoulish and surprising ways.
One of the best vampire movies ever made.
This timeless classic is a testimony to the craft of director Edgar G Ulmer before his career lurched into the quickie arena.
There's no denying that Castle's directorial crassness does actually supply some genuinely frightening moments.
This Hitchcock classic somehow strayed from favour for a while, yet in the realm of popular mythology it is now rivalled only by Vertigo or Psycho.
Lavishly produced and visually gorgeous (thanks to the atmospheric photography of Floyd Crosby), Corman's gothic creepfest is still scary after all these years.
movie_title: The Fall of the House of Usher (1960)

movie_review_blurb: This Dogme-driven apocalyptic nightmare from director Danny Boyle is a tense, exciting and terrifying horror.
This Universal classic not only established Lon Chaney Jr as a horror star but also instigated most of the cinematic werewolf lore concerning pentagrams, the Moon and the fatality of silver.
Intelligence and subtle wit inform debut director Lorene Scafaria's heartfelt look at unlikely romance blossoming in the shadow of Earth's obliteration by a giant asteroid.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A vulgar, variable and very French take on infidelity.
Makes the most of a simple premise and single location setting, the cast are uniformly good, and the impressive creature delivers nastily effective splatter chaos.
The classical/rap/hip-hop soundtrack is smoking and the 3-D visuals add immeasurably to the all-action routines

Dunstan makes his directorial debut with this fast-paced, suspenseful horror that wastes no time on pointless exposition, but instead tosses plenty of genuinely tense moments into this primal fear-fest.
The glow of originality may have dimmed, but Pixar's third rummage in the toy box delivers exactly what it's supposed to, with appealing fringe benefits.

From the magical realist opening to the operatic finale, everything in this ravishingly photographed scrapbook of sun-kissed memories and picture-postcard nostalgia is sweeping, involving, romantic and disarmingly sentimental.

As Natali's potent allegory about child-rearing turns deadly, absurdity is, thankfully, just about kept in check through committed performances and the director's deflating of the most risible moments with well-judged levity.
Even if you've heard the one about the high-stakes dance contest that Manhattan street performers must win to hold onto their communal home, you've never seen it done quite like this.
A barrage of spectacular special effects in search of an appealing story.
Aside from the 3D gimmick, there's not much on offer here that the low-budget original didn't include, with plenty of comical gore, snappy thrills and in-joke references.
It's efficient enough, in the vein of a Swedish episode of Wallander, but fans of the novels will no doubt overlook its deficiencies and thrill to it.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [A] dull and messy ride through supernatural Clint Eastwood territory.
Where the original was joltingly inventive and disturbing, this is just second-hand fright.
Anderson heaves axes, artillery, shattered glass and The Thing-style dogs at the camera to wincing effect, but it still only adds up to a lame, by-the-numbers horror.
Patience with the braindead script's predictability runs thin as the pacing slackens off and the contrived sickness continually fails to shock.
Green choreographs the dangling trio from a multitude of intriguing angles, showing a keen eye for moody menace and compelling gruesomeness.
More maudlin than subtle, more schmaltzy than emotionally true.
Landis pounces on every contemporary innovation and social issue for its inherent gallows humour to craft an entertaining version of the historical facts.
This Americanisation of the elegantly eerie Swedish cult hit Let the Right One In is an honourable effort.
Once the ace special effects and full-on monster mania take prominence over the soap opera plot, it does become weirdly fascinating.
This nightmarish satire on the more cut-throat aspects of the Hong Kong property market manages to be both a thoughtful social commentary and gory slasher without any real awkwardness in tone.
The film's stark approach to the fantastic and supernatural won't appeal to the mainstream, despite a distinctive and visually arresting presentation.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One of the oddest and quirkiest nightmares before Christmas.
Wonderful escapist fantasy flows non-stop in the best instalment in the Narnia series to date.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Very much in the Dante family-friendly fantasy tradition of Gremlins, this nostalgic exercise in mild scares resembles the director's segment from Twilight Zone: the Movie in many creepy/fun respects...
The mix of arcane ritual magic, bleak social drama and Terminator tropes quickly begins to feel muddled.
This painfully low-budget effort is barely passable as a TV drama let alone a movie experience...
Though it's technically impressive and has an epic sweep, the lack of suspense and emotional involvement makes this little more than a chase movie in ancient garb.
Full of gaudy Art Deco excess, surprise charm and sardonic violence, this deadpan send-up is a classy fright delight.
A deserved cult masterpiece, this tale of the macabre, with its blood-freezing shock ending, is incredible, disturbing and, once seen, never forgotten.
It may not be particularly original in terms of content or style, but Oren Peli's decisively no-budget horror creates a surprisingly effective sense of dread.
This cosmic joke isn't as bad as Kelly's previous picture, Southland Tales, but it's still a total mess, even if it is a stylish looking one.
Bigger looking but less frightening.
McCormick's lacklustre reboot is just another indistinguishable psycho thriller.
The film as a whole is cold and uninvolving, even with Sophia Loren adding some much-needed Italian authenticity to the retro hollowness.

With beautiful Blade Runner-style cityscapes, smartly conceived takes on the vampire mythos (sun-proofed cars and video mirrors), inventively engineered shocks and copious blood loss, this is an engagingly skilful blend.

Top-notch performances give viewers Reasons to be Cheerful - Milner is terrific and Serkis is the tour de force at the film's centre, capturing the charisma that made the destructively complex Dury the "housewives' favourite" punk rocker.
This is a likeable enough Southern-fried fantasia but it lacks the transporting magical quality of other more memorable Disney efforts.
It may lack the fresh irreverence and excitement of the first adventure, but there are noteworthy set pieces.
This preachy animation parable remains resolutely dull and lifeless.
Not only is the film effective in making points about potential quarantine dangers, but also in how they could be horribly mishandled, and it's all frighteningly underlined by the shocking finale.
This continually astonishes, enchants and beguiles.
The wavering tone is as uncertain as Alice's decision-making, while the added-on 3-D is a distraction and as unconvincing as the entire misconceived venture.

While the viewer will remain one step ahead of the story at all times, director Christian Alvart manages to keep the emotionally charged events moving at a fair clip to gloss over the mounting credibility factors.
More than a little silly, it veers between high camp and supernatural hokum as an overqualified cast gives the portentous, Bible-based action far more conviction than it deserves.
As an exercise in pure style over clichéd content Shutter Island weaves an impressive and gripping spell.
A smartly budgeted and often scary chiller.
Where this highly appealing comedy adventure really excels is with awesome visuals that rival Avatar's.
Vaughn's witty verve, instinctive knack for bizarre counterpoint and sheer bravado speed the cartoon violence towards a manic action climax.
How do you raise a child in prison? Argentinian director Pablo Trapero tackles that question with affecting skill in this initially squalid yet ultimately uplifting social drama.
Decked out with terrific Czech locations, Klaus Badelt's rousing score, neat CGI visual effects keen biblical imagery and a solid supporting cast, the imperfections can be forgiven.
Seamlessly and vigorously conveyed, this satisfying segment raises the storytelling and visual-effects bar for the entire series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As an action-packed visual feast ... Tron Legacy is truly astonishing...
Bracewell's lofty ambitions are clear to see in what is an obvious labour of love, but they simply don't come off in a mess of clichés and barely adequate performances.
Favreau's solid adaptation of a popular 2006 graphic novel remains true to both genres while being confidently grounded in western lore for maximum novelty value.
It is darkly comic, brutally violent and a dynamo of dizzying fright stuff.
The slow-building, low-key creepiness finally explodes with a welcome rattling ingenuity.
It shifts effortlessly between a twisted study in obsessive psychosis and barbed sardonic satire.
Although it's exceptionally silly and takes itself way too seriously, the movie will give lovers of expertly faked beefcake action their sword-and-sandal fix.
The visuals are frequently spectacular and the environmental concerns are admirable, but this simply doesn't have the charm of the original.
Tense, smart and suitably gruesome, this certainly delivers the goods.
That suave, scene-stealing cat from Shrek 2 finally gets his own swashbuckling adventure and it couldn't be a more colourful feline fairy tale.
It all remains on the light-hearted, harmless and inoffensive side despite bad-taste gags and gory Yuletide violence.
Embracing the techniques and look of the times, and paying homage to numerous silent classics and Citizen Kane, this loving, warm pastiche is a sheer delight.

War movie clichés, gung ho derring-do and seamless special effects all fit together well in a pleasingly retro environment that boasts enough sci-fi paraphernalia to put an end to the argument that it may be too old-fashioned.
A uniquely moving odyssey that subtly outlines both the suffering of the First World War and the humanity amid so much loss of life.

This poignant tale has an irresistible, heart-warming energy and also boasts sharp dialogue, skilfully interwoven subplots and a treasure trove of British stars giving a masterclass in ensemble acting.
The melodrama creaks as much as the nursery rocking chair, but the grim resolution adds an unexpectedly uplifting and bittersweet twist.
Crank directors Mark Neveldine and Brian Taylor bring nothing of note to this hackneyed follow-up to the money-raking original.
Ross keeps the sci-fi themes vivid and relevant, the camerawork jittery and involving and the action speedy and thrilling.
In this worthy successor, it's once again the dancing that counts, and this sure-fire crowd-pleaser delivers sensational high-energy routines to some great pop hits.
A remarkable and genuinely captivating original.
The third Hasbro toy-to-film franchise (after Transformers and GI Joe) doesn't mess with a winning format.
"Welcome to rock bottom" says David Hasselhoff, reduced to badly emulating his role in Baywatch. He never spoke a truer word.
Haunting and heartbreaking, director Jean-Marc Vallée's romantic drama is an electrifying multilayered experience.
Frankly, it's all tedious on the western front in this bum-numbing bore.
In this pleasant slice of family fare, teen Josh Hutcherson and stepfather Dwayne Johnson trace the actual location of author Jules Verne's supposedly fictional island.
There's an innocent sweetness about this showcase for Christina Aguilera's vocal and dance skills that just about excuses its utter hokiness.
The cartoon viciousness and wild overacting only add to the winningly exuberant excess of what is a startling feature debut for the director.
The technical wizardry on display is perfectly crafted and fires the imagination like never before.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some terrific locations in Hungary and the Austrian Alps, this ho-hum 14th-century history lesson remains routine and unconvincing right up to its all-hell-breaks-loose CGI-heavy finale.
"Everything before this has been crap", says Rogen during the explosive finale. Many will agree.
Combines polished storytelling, witty scripting and relatable emotions to create a smart, snappy and sparkling tale with appeal to both kids and adults.
It thoughtfully reflects on how deep sorrow and melancholy can change existence, with both Damon and de France really making their performances count.
It's the locations, eerie sets, special effects and marine photography that count here, and all are impressively spectacular.
Coarsely adapted from the young adult novel, this has an inoffensive TV feel, and its uninspired number is up way before the finale erupts in stale CGI fireworks.
A tremendously exciting and challenging thriller that builds unnervingly to a stunning conclusion.
A non-stop riot of gratuitous sex, full-on violence, gory gunfights and explosive car crashes make this fun chase-and-chiller combo a high-energy trash extravaganza.
An effective mix of surprising fact and hard-edged fiction.
Unravelling the jigsaw clues is a lot of fun, while the changes rung during the familiar ticking-bomb countdown finale marks Collet-Serra as a genuinely gifted genre specialist.
The film is shot in a documentary-style that's enhanced by using actual convicts as extras.
Finnish music video director Antti J Jokinen ... overdoes the shadowy film noir style, while skimping on everything else from believable motivation to standard genre theatrics.
A compelling twist on the Faustian-pact dilemma that builds to a truly memorable, if starkly horrifying, ending.
There are the usual life lessons to be learned, but under Saldanha's light touch they seamlessly blend with the airborne action and riotous musical interludes.
The Company of Wolves did it so much better back in 1984.
Fantastic fun.
A dourly humourless, futuristic farrago.
This grandiose globetrotting fantasy boasts plentiful action spectacle and effective character-based drama set in an age of civil unrest and Cold War paranoia.
The movie is as busy and crisply detailed as ever, and the action sequences involving rickshaw chases, martial arts dust-ups and cannonball juggling score high.
[DeMornay] delights and startles with a vicious portrayal of familial cruelty and wanton bloodlust.
This is a galvanizing must-see for all lovers of seat-edge suspense cinema.
As much a character-driven coming-of-age tale as a gritty horror fable, writer/director Jim Mickle's socially relevant shocker is The Road with vampires.
War of the Worlds meets The Hurt Locker in director Jonathan Liebesman's down-and-dirty alien-invasion flick.
Guillermo del Toro's mastery of fantasy film-making and his understanding of the multi-faceted richness of the genre guides this sequel to visually imaginative and intricately detailed heights.
A glossy, stylistic, cosmopolitan and jagged mystery firmly entrenched in Hitchcockian paranoia.
movie_title: L'uccello dalle piume di cristallo (The Bird With the Crystal Plumage) (1970)

movie_review_blurb: This grim spin on Alice in Wonderland is del Toro's finest work to date.
The inventive visual side is stirring, dazzling and vibrant, an exemplar of creative grandeur and finesse.
Effectively self-contained psychological horror bursts into full-blown science fiction in director Dan Trachtenberg's robust debut feature.
It builds slowly through wrenching family drama to imaginative sci-fi sustained as much by heart and emotion as thrilling special effects.
The soundtrack - which is among the star's best work - is reduced to the level of background music. It's a vanity venture, not even worth watching for kitsch value.
One for devoted fans only.
This compelling biopic is a hugely entertaining, compassionate and ultimately rather touching portrait of self-delusion and devotion.
Hadzihalilovic's aquatic fairy tale feels like the bastard son of Jacques Cousteau and David Cronenberg.

here's an engaging chemistry between the five boozers, while the surprise cameos, early 1990s indie soundtrack, zany violence and visual effects add to a self-aware, matey romp that slips down a treat.
There's lots of furry fun to be had in this familiar canine caper, despite the overstretched plot being overpopulated with too many crazy characters.

Twinkly-eyed, vulnerable and melancholic, Rylance exudes soulful warmth pours off the screen in a well-rounded, elegant characterisation -- even if the CGI does sometimes leave him looking like a Middle-earth Noel Edmonds.
It's a solid shocker throughout, with horror icon Larry Fessenden as our radio DJ guide to the menacing morality lessons.

It boasts four comedy stars at the top of their game and a director fresh from revolutionising contemporary comedy, but this reboot of one of the biggest hits in the comedy fantasy arena is uninspired, bland and lame-brained.
Collet-Serra knows his genre stuff and layers this basic girl-in-bikini v monster premise with shrewd tension and submerged suspense, finding inspired new ways to terrorise.

Though it isn't vintage Pedro Almodóvar by any stretch, this sumptuous saga of love, loss, grief and guilt features enough touchstones to the unconventional Spanish director's previous repertoire to please his loyal cult.
Gruesomely visceral and startlingly vicious, this is mainstream horror at its best.

An entrancing marvel of peerless stop-motion puppetry and creative CGI, this visually dazzling fable woven around richly imagined metaphors for love, loneliness and loss elevates Laika Entertainment to Pixar level.
Related in gritty Scorsese fashion with striking Hollywood style, and revealing Trapero's top-notch storytelling prowess and expert technical flair, the movie builds to a truly stunning climax.
There's really nothing that special here, but an upgraded arsenal of equipment (drone camera, GPS, etc.) produces a far more visceral experience.
It startles and chills before McCarthy offers genuine hope for humankind to define the best and most unusual zombie movie since 28 Days Later.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film-makers are consistently inventive in ways you can't un-see, with images you truly won't forget.
Not to be taken seriously at any point, this is just a crowd-pleasingly nasty revenge saga, which builds to a surprising and unexpectedly downbeat desert showdown.
The unique outrage oozing from every slippery frame is made palatable by sheer gonzo lunacy.
There's plenty of subtle satire and double entendres for young and old alike to savour.
It's for [Chaney's] inimitable genius alone that this sprawling saga is now most fondly remembered.
Its shortcomings are fairly easy to overlook.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Roth's beautifully photographed, man's-inhumanity-to-man tract offers brutal thrills, grisly gore and bleak, thought-provoking horror, served up with the signature aplomb that his fans appreciate.
Expertly building on the renewed energy injected into the Mission: Impossible franchise with 2011's Ghost Protocol, this fifth episode roars along like a sleek, well-oiled machine.
The straining pop art production design and heavy-handed genre-blurring only results in a frantic, thrown-together mess.
A bleak, uncompromising look into the brutal death of innocence.
The James Bond series started in great style with this cleverly conceived dose of sheer escapism that, unlike later episodes, remained true to the essence of Ian Fleming's super-spy novels.
It's also one of the funniest ruminations on American values, as the car showroom becomes a warped microcosm of society.
It never looks less than fabulous, even when director Joe Wright's high-flying ambitions overcrowd the senses and the sensational.
Even those well-acquainted with the genre should find enough to enjoy in the stylish set-pieces that feature plenty of bloody action.
Diesel centres the magical mischief with his winning muscular charm, while priestly advisor Michael Caine adds a welcome touch of charismatic class.
This exceptional spy escapade is far-fetched mayhem of the highest order, with a welcome accent on character realism rather than just spectacular sets.

In a welcome return to the gritty glamour of such early outings as From Russia with Love, this 19th James Bond adventure effortlessly juggles a hard-hitting story with all the expected "super spy" embellishments.
Zada keeps the tiresome terrors coming, though they're undermined by his consistently formulaic approach.
Sometimes shocking, unexpectedly charming and ultimately rather moving.
Expertly executed without a dull stretch, despite an elongated running time, the second instalment based on Suzanne Collins's bestselling dystopian fantasy trilogy is a top-flight escapist adventure.
Sure, it's a kick-ass Bourne on a budget, but it has a strikingly mature sense of style, slick wall-to-wall stunts, plus wit and suspense.
A stunning masterpiece, front-loaded with atmospheric mood and poignant tenderness.
This low-key saga rings true without resorting to melodrama.
If you can stomach it, this profoundly moving film will leave you dazed.
You do have to dig a little deeper in more key areas to find the sly gold in them thar snow-crested hills. But it is there, if you come to this good, bad and ugly deconstruction well prepared.
This typically eccentric and multidimensional movie from director Nicolas Roeg transforms Walter Tevis's novel into an enigmatic and chilling mosaic of corporate satire and effective science fiction.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from mawkish family flashbacks, this wonky tribute to heroic courage works best when being visually dynamic and brutally immersive in its sensational combat sequences.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: So tired and over-familiar, even the basic supernatural ingredients fail to cohere in the engaging and spine-chilling way that they should.
It works like a charm, delivering furtive glances and fetid cadavers in equally absurd proportion to remain a commodious and dastardly fine pleasure throughout.
Forget the overworked plot... Marvel instead at the state-of-the-art technical wizardry and fizzing action that's just enough to keep nostalgic wistfulness at bay.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Once more the level of conceptual cleverness and ingenious visual design creates real magic.
The scares may be dated, but the miniaturised special effects, relying on oversized props, are still enthralling, and the offbeat fantasy atmosphere Browning expertly conjures up is highly unusual.
This was the classic that single-handedly revived traditional British Gothic and firmly placed the "Hammer House of Horror" on the global gore map.
An engaging combination of nerve-jangling suspense, graphic swerves into unexpected shock, queasy surgical procedures and the blackest humour.
It's essentially the intuitive accuracy of shattered Sackhoff's performance that makes this Old Dark House chestnut worth catching.
Genre fans with strong stomachs will find this a memorably tasty morsel. Those with more delicate dispositions should probably wait for the American remake.
An easy-going romantic comedy with uneven charms, this lightweight affair occupies that small space between John Hughes nostalgia and My Big Fat Greek Wedding vitality.
Probably the best and most complete thrill-ride since Mad Max: Fury Road.
With a sensational performance by Watts, it's a triple-strength masterpiece that will more than satisfy the die-hard Lynch mob and may even gain a receptive new audience for the Sultan of Strange.

With no supernatural elements, only the barest neo-realist approach to the horror, this nihilistic meditation on teenage angst and the defence mechanisms needed to protect the vulnerable spirit will disappoint genre lovers.
Ritchie's tale of warlocks, Londinium docks and 2000 smoking arrows is undoubtedly his finest and most commanding movie to date.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Schumer's mix of brutal honesty and brilliant timing ekes every last titter out of Katie Dippold's solidly witty, sometimes hilarious script, and Hawn is an endearing if occasionally passive-aggressive foil ...

The film showcases a fantastic array of top-notch acting, spearheaded by force-of-nature Brian Cox, who gives a tremendous performance as the charismatic politician who inspired Great Britain to resist Adolf Hitler.

There isn't an original bone in its generic body, but this undistinguished reboot of the popular 1990s TV show has enough colourful adventure, upbeat action and genial thrills to satisfy its target audience.
It may not be an easy watch, but the awesome visual benefits will keep you in your seat.
Director Tom Holland's totally banal and pedestrian horror movie is the "thinner" end of the wedge as far as awful adaptations of King's books go.
At best it's a sexy gut-punch of grisly gunfire and A-list gorgeousness, one that will make you wish for secret agent Lorraine Broughton's rapid return in something a bit more substantial.
Nothing works in the directing debut of noted character actor Jason Flemyng.
Proving just what can be done with a now familiar concept if lavished with care, attention and craft, It really is one of the most gripping and glowing Stephen King movie adaptations.
[David] Bruckner pulls off merciless tension between the well-played-out bickering to get up an uncommonly spooky head of scream.

Injecting fresh energy into Chris Van Allsburg's hugely successful 1981 book, director Jake Kasdan's rollicking mix of It's a Wonderful Life and Tomb Raider finds comfortable humour and heart at the soft centre of its dog-eared source material.
This mid-section marker in the current trilogy simply doesn't disappoint, realising the courage of its convictions with an intelligent story and a heart-swelling emotional resonance.
Dementedly twisted, like one of Jigsaw's fiendishly constructed torture traps, the Saw franchise screams back to life with the Spierig Brothers' ace eighth episode in the fun fear franchise.
A joyously uplifting potpourii of visual resplendence, stylish choreography and solid gold magic, one engineered to approximate the lavish spectacle the movie musical once offered ...
More spoofy than spooky -- although the nod to The Texas Chain Saw Massacre is fan-boy gold -- this flippant frightener is agreeably lowbrow B-movie fun.
In comparison to the moody tragedy of the Don Siegel cult original, feels so blandly inconsequential.
The third instalment of Universal's classic series features Boris Karloff's last fling as the Monster and is a superior shocker all round.
If your children are feeling nostalgic, then this colourful junk will while away a couple of very mindless hours.
movie_title: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Condon (who has musical pedigree with Dreamgirls) is clearly having fun throughout his ambitious flight of chocolate-box imagination.
This is a text-book example of top-grade ghoulish horror from Hammer's golden era.
Lorre literally steals the show with a masterfully bravura performance in a superior slice of psychological horror.
Touches of ethereal gothic atmosphere and a neat funereal flamboyancy make this slick shock package a cut above the rest.
The standard plot now looks hackneyed, and the cueball-headed Dekker is stereotypically crazy. However, the impressive array of oversize props make this a lot of fun to watch.

The first sequel to the Claude Rains classic, while more modestly scaled than its predecessor, still receives a first-class treatment from director Joe May and, in many instances, surpasses the visual magic of the original.
This horrendously funny gross-out shocker from Lord of the Rings and King Kong director Peter Jackson is a brilliant black comedy and the ultimate gore movie.
[It] is by far the best movie adaptation of the stock spoof horror play set in a creepy mansion where masked menace lurks. It's also a superior mystery chiller in its own right.
Williams gives a sensitive portrayal of a man hounded by the media and consigned to a freak's world, whose descent into being and nothingness provides a memorable climax.
The vintage feel, complete with old-fashioned titles, period visual style and even fake reel change marks, makes for a satisfying if bloodless shocker, a vast improvement on the first.

Forget all you know or think you know about the Marvel Cinematic Universe. ... Derrickson has blown the glitter dust off one of its second-string superheroes and provided him with a barnstorming origin story ...
This art house Euro hokum lacks verve and technique.
[A] cautionary tale that tackles modern schooling issues and refreshes terror-tot fiction like Village of the Damned.

Not only opens up a whole innovative universe of dark cinematic surprise but also exciting new territory for Potterphiles as the wizarding world moves from sedate rural England to the helter skelter jazz age of prohibition era New York.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The well-created atmospheres of bleak desolation, shivery seat-edged thrills and sheer-intensity of spirit-world dabbling paper over the more nonsensical sections of the scattershot narrative that does eventually build to quite a chilling crescendo.
Coupled with the Parkour-inspired stunts Kurzel insists on keeping the CGI in check for the feel of an old school adventure and executes the action with a great deal of care and attention to detail.
Silence would benefit from being shorter than its 161 minutes and it does become a tad repetitious, but Scorsese is clearly unloading his psyche in a very entrenched, passionate and specific way.
The goth fetish horror series carries on regardless in this agreeable fifth episode, the first from a female director.
Shyamalan gets his Hitchcock groove on in this deviously playful horror thriller that satisfies as a companion piece to his earlier, more successful works.
If this is, indeed, the last in the record-breaking sci-fi horror series then original writer/director Paul WS Anderson ends his video-game franchise in satisfying high style.
A gripping, inspirational biopic with simplicity, tact and intelligence.
Madder than a box of frogs - or should that be an isolation chamber of eels? - director Gore Verbinski's rather meandering supernatural fantasy remains an elegant elixir-of-life shocker.

The feature debut of director Ben Parker is a busy if ultimately tedious existential thriller, though he does show a talent for keeping things visually interesting with this high-concept, tight-space tale.
Intriguing and different enough to earn its stripes in the transformation genre.
Just horrible.
The thirteenth Star Trek movie adventure pleasingly and emphatically returns the latest reboot and its replacement cast to the vibe and spirit of the classic TV series.
No target is safe and no shock too extreme in the mind-boggling climax to director Tom Six's contentious trilogy.
While not of Disney/Pixar animation quality - especially in the appearance of the humans - this lively fantasy packs in enough tropical incident and vivid action to pass muster.
A winning found-footage horror that also works as a sly commentary on the urban legend business.
Absolute nonsense, highly entertaining (on certain camp levels) - and never boring.
One of the funniest bad movies ever made.
Until Field of Dreams came along, director John Hancock's moving buddy drama held the title of the best baseball movie ever made.
Crowe's greatest strength is the way he focuses on those smaller moments in life that are rarely reflected in movies.
Audacious, controversial, directional, important and totally unique, you'll either love it or hate it. But see it!
Funny, tragic, brilliant and unmissable.
The haunted-mirror scenario gets an impressive workout in writer/director Mike Flanagan's expansion of his award-winning 2005 short.

The script is remorselessly smutty, the one-liners are below average and the giant mechanical spider climax endlessly drawn out, but the wildly inventive gizmos give entertainment value and draw a shield over the numerous flaws.
Occasionally charming, yet completely unoriginal, this is dumb fun, no more, no less.
Familiarity quickly breeds contempt, with Bullock rather obviously just along for the ride.
The cult crime novel by Joe R Lansdale is skilfully adapted by director Jim Mickle (Stake Land) and his regular screenwriting partner Nick Damici into noir-ish cutting-edge pulp fiction.
Wonderfully evoking the feel and spirit of the era, this is one of those rare movies you live through rather than watch.
Groovy music by the Sandals, a five-piece surfing outfit, accompany the beautiful images and Brown's hip surfer-speak is a history lesson in itself.
The cult 1960s TV series gets royally shafted by Hollywood in this stunningly designed blockbuster that's stunningly awful in every other department.
Lindsay Lohan takes on a dual role in director Chris Sivertson's twisty, perversely fascinating psycho thriller.
Writer/director M Night Shyamalan's once glorious reputation is tarnished further by this tediously juvenile fantasy adventure.
The real torture in this vengeful cyber-spirit saga comes from having to sit through such ugly trash.

Attaining a near perfect Disney-style mix of colourful inventiveness, engaging characters, eye-popping spectacle (especially in its 3D version) and fun-scary set pieces, it's a polished delight with ageless appeal.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Complete with a Xanadu-style dance routine, Pam Grier as Pluto's mother indulging in tired blaxploitation moves and rent-a-cameo John Cleese as a virtual reality chauffeur, this is a flop of epic proportions.
Buckles are truly swashed and derring-do effectively done in this 12th-century adventure, which simply sets out to entertain handsomely and does so with a great deal of dash, flash and panache.
The result is a modern masterpiece.

In this cracking jungle-set treasure hunt, director Robert Zemeckis spices up a deliberately old-fashioned matinée adventure with tongue-in-cheek gags, unpredictably clever touches and top-of-the-range action.
Even if the visuals are rather drab and the action more brisk than imaginative, there's enough menace and suspense to create an entertaining diversion.
The highest-grossing Japanese film of all time is a luxuriously animated legend of ancient gods going head to head with mankind and industry over the balance of nature.
Only the deliciously demented imagination of Edward Scissorhands director Tim Burton could have come up with such a dark vision of the holiday season.
This smartly scripted Cinderella love story is crammed with charm and the expert direction of Jon Turteltaub hits all the right emotional buttons.
A powerful tragedy full of surprises and visual style.
A dazzling fairy-tale adventure that evokes the studio's early 1990s refreshment of its animated output through an injection of Broadway talent.

Spielberg uses stark, brutal realism to put over his powerful points about racism and ethnic cleansing, and the use of stunning black-and-white photography and gritty hand-held camera footage give the film a potent documentary style.
[A] tawdry, strident yet deeply affecting tale.

While it's not quite as original or witty as it could have been, this unashamedly glossy take on vampire mythology has a clever script that's packed with twists, and builds to a surprisingly tense climax.
Lower your expectations and this overplayed urban combat drama will reward with a few tense moments.
It all comes across as risk-averse, over-baked and hollow.
Imagine a mix of Sky High and The Incredibles with all the fun, laughs and clever adventure taken out and you've got director Peter Hewitt's atrocious comic-book fiasco.
It's a fabulous-looking package, elegantly orchestrated by del Toro, who has an unerring eye for undead iconography, which he takes to visually imaginative extremes.
Flat characters are stuck in underdeveloped situations in this attempt by first-time directors Deborah Kaplan and Harry Elfont to recapture the mood of a John Hughes 1980s teen comedy.
It's pleasant enough, with Fraser's goofy charm particularly winning.
Be prepared to be completely bowled over by a director at the peak of his talents and in full control of top-notch material.
Seven is a work of extraordinary style, upsetting power and narrative daring.
This exquisite evocation of the 1950s tear-jerkers of director Douglas Sirk is gorgeously designed, stunningly photographed, ravishingly scored and beautifully acted.
Wittily written with a nice eye for sharp detail, it's hard sci-fi action all the way.
Youngsters will love this hip spoof on hardware movies.
It may seem somewhat dated these days, but it would probably be fair to credit this Disney movie with being the forerunner of the Toy Story movies.
Although highly derivative of ET, WarGames and others, this science-fiction drama is still a charming, lightweight diversion.
It's the same mix of colourfully frantic action, sharp sight gags and catchy musical numbers.
Jim Mickle's savvy re-imagining of the 2010 Mexican art-house horror marks a quantum leap forward in maturity and style for the Stake Land director.
The sharp, if expletive-ridden, dialogue in Oliver Stone's script and the vivid cinematography of John A Alonzo help make De Palma's urban shocker a modern-day classic.
It's Verhoeven's scabrous dissection of American social issues, trashy sitcom culture and corporate greed that makes this comic-book opus a subversive and thought-provoking edge-of-the-seat treat.

Elias Koteas scores as a mock-turtle vigilante, and there are some nifty turtle effects from the Henson Creature Shop, but little else hits the target, despite Barron covering the cracks with fast editing.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: The three non-professionals playing the rubbish-sifting comrades exude a believable solidarity and charismatic energy, though Brazilian star Selton Mello overdoes his role as a sadistic cop.
A thoughtful, if wonky, small-scale epic of retro-futurism.
A hectic but better than expected entertainment.
Uplifting and full of that hard-to-capture sparkling sense of wonder, this is an enthralling addition to the trustworthy Disney brand of memorable, magical fairy tales.

Another irresistible swirl of heart-warming life lessons, funny valentines and intoxicating local Indian colour, this captivating sequel is not second best at all, more a worthy companion piece to the 2011 crowd-pleaser.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's the recycled plot, tired romantic complications, hackneyed rivalries and soap operatics between the dance-offs that are the trouble.
It's weird, wonderful and wildly funny.
ET meets Lilo & Stitch in this sweet, screwball culture clash comedy adapted from Adam Rex's children's novel The True Meaning of Smekday.
Under the expert guidance of TV series writer/director Paul Tibbitt, sophisticated adult gags jostle with inspired childish silliness, each element dovetailing for increased inventiveness.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like an artefact from the Children's Film Foundation era, only with misplaced adult humour and bad language.
The nostalgic delights in Waters's reform school drool are often more subtle than his other period offering, Hairspray, but it's still a polished debunking of pop culture from the "Pope of Trash".

The monster muscle-car franchise continues to relentlessly assault the senses in this globe-trotting sequel, with horror maestro James Wan's direction adding extra high-style brilliance to proceedings.
Gosling is clearly angling for a parable on American consumerism, but he's more concerned with arresting fantasy-noir visuals, surreal dreamscapes and weird atmospheres than a coherent story.
It all makes for a powerful metaphor for the human condition during wartime, executed with remarkable skill, confidence and an astute fantasy feel.
Traviss is clearly searching for cockney cool and "lots of layers, like life" but can't find either in the one-note flimsiness of the plastic plot that's worsened by weak ensemble acting.
Jalmari Helander's follow-up to the dark, cult Christmas thriller Rare Exports is a pleasing enough escapist diversion.

Making the most of its modest attributes and a wrenching central performance by TV regular and Hellboy veteran Rupert Evans, this Irish chiller lurches from unspoken eeriness to outright horror as it plots a familiar paranormal trajectory.

Though it's impossible not to get caught up in our hero's Russian training programme, or to root for his climactic victory, the mawkish montages accompanied by blaring music are no substitute for plot shading.
Quick, call on entomologist Michael Caine and a hive of Hollywood has-beens to out-ham each other while reciting terrible dialogue and getting stung by coloured Styrofoam pellets!
Registers an eight on the entertainment Richter scale.
Roth comes unstuck with this silly, unconvincing and repetitive home-invasion shocker.
A tiresome shambles ...
Scott's visionary thriller makes the acid rain/neon-drenched Los Angeles of 2019 a far colder, more violent and depressing place.

A confident yet thoughtful performance from a bulked-up Bradley Cooper is the solid centre of director Clint Eastwood's absorbingly matter-of-fact biopic of the most lethal sniper in US military history.
Leigh's bravura mix of comedy, tragedy, violence and warmth marks this uncompromising exposé as British film-making at its finest.
The denouement is unexpected and satisfying, while the peril provided by the Second World War backdrop cleverly matches the supernatural suspense.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If it does become faintly dull and preachy, the trim humour and detailing - the CHiPs spoof CHoPs, Motorjito cocktails, the pickup truck with superb pickup lines - soon get it squarely back on the fun runway.
Up is breathtaking in its imaginative detail and astonishing in its emotional range.
Director Adrian Lyne caught the post-disco visual mood of the time to win over even the most cynical viewer.
Works on most of its profound levels.
Russell's razzle-dazzle hallucinogenic style certainly hits bullseye.
The two leads captivate as the besotted psychotic duo in a nightmarish odyssey that's offbeat right up to its enigmatic conclusion.
Perhaps it is slightly one-note. Yet this bolder vision conveys the essence of co-director Frank Miller's art better than ever.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of the all-time classics of pretentiously incomprehensible cinema.
[A] leisurely paced but ultimately rewarding study of terminal addiction in all its many forms.
A nonstop giggle from start to finish, this beguiling grab-bag of time-travel clichés, hard-rock music and Valley-speaking cool dudes is a flawless, purpose-built junk movie.
A charmless if flashy affair.
There's the usual winning mix of wisecracking banter, overblown war craft and mad combat skills with a take-no-prisoners attitude and jokey references to the action heroes' pasts ...
Nimbly directed by Casey La Scala, and performed with engaging conviction, this Book of Revelations faith-based shocker is surprisingly effective.
That creepy grinning doll from The Conjuring gets its own origin story in this disappointingly banal supernatural spin-off.
Like a British Saturday Night Fever, it captures the look, energy and exuberance of a youth culture, while not shying away from the more violent and amphetamine-fuelled darker sides.
An entertaining smooth ride.
Jennifer Kent's striking debut feature is a bold and intensely emotional psychological horror.
Revelling in its B-movie conventions to little dramatic effect, this intergalactic slasher is often unintentionally hilarious.

With drab-chic production, Christopher Eccleston's marvellous central performance and a pop nostalgia soundtrack, the odious miscarriage of justice comes vividly to life to scandalise anew those unfamiliar with the true facts.
The age-old seance question "Is anybody there?" can be equally aimed at those behind the camera.

The excitement is dampened by a draggy middle where Moses gets married and a tedious epilogue, but Scott's keen ability to explain scripture miracles in credible terms is this biblical blockbuster's major asset.

The 1977 Broadway hit has suffered an overblown 1982 adaptation, a sickly 1999 TV movie and a terrible stage sequel. But the worst hadn't happened to it until this awkwardly updated, misconceived and sloppy remake.
It will be a hard heart indeed that won't be affected by the way the story is resolved.
For Brocka and his characters, Manila is a libertarian dystopia, where poverty breeds its own predators and victims as the city's poor grasp for the little wealth that hasn't yet been distributed.
movie_title: Manila In The Claws Of Light (Maynila: Sa mga kuko ng liwanag) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent of being repeatedly hit over the head with a food mixer.
In comparison to its superior predecessors, Detour's redemption plot feels banal and slight.

McG may strip down his approach and serve up a variety of slick, well-paced shoot-outs and car chases, but his technical skill can't quite overcome the story's lazy sense of humor and incomprehensible account of international espionage.
Like Antoine Doinel in The 400 Blows, Tarek has a way of using defiance and sarcasm to make himself seem smarter than any ostensible authority figure.
Rachel Boynton remarkably reveals just how much influence corporate interests have on public wellbeing, and how rarely Ghanaians are part of any debate.
A creepy, claustrophobic atmosphere.
Huck Botko's film asks us to laugh at, even revel in, the misadventures of womanizing men, even as it condemns them for their behavior.
Like many films that contrast the simplicity of a rural community against the confusion of city life, The Grand Seduction exhibits a patriarchal, xenophobic attitude.
About as good as it can get for this type of picture. It's utter tosh, but impossible not to enjoy.
Tom Shoval, who eschews stylistic flourishes in order to focus on character, leaves the film's heavy lifting to the actors and his own screenplay.
Gilbert's full length debut isn't a complete shambles but where passion and tumult should exist, there is only a misguided intent to be found.
Its hilarious yet sombre approach harks back to the world of Hal Hartley, whilst creating a wholly original and at times perplexing incarnation of American indie cinema.
Nobody's Daughter Haewon is the Korean answer to Wong Kar Wai's Chunking Express, a moving statement of a country's people separated by the times.
movie_title: Nugu-ui ttal-do anin Haewon (Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps a documentary to be more admired than loved.
Pandora's Promise gives up enough information to tease the curiosity of doubting individuals but unfortunately as a piece of subversive, cogent filmmaking - it's a box of empty promises.
The ill-conceived structure and Bernal's anomalous presence sadly diminishes the impact of the material.
If you survive past the blunt, uncompromising structure of the first third, you are rewarded with a beautifully peculiar tale that evokes the sensations and frustrations of youth with lyrical aplomb.
movie_title: Mary Is Happy, Mary Is Happy (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A bit of a damp squib in comparison to its peers.
Futuro Beach resists easy definition; life is full of blurred lines and Aïnouz knows it.

If there's a lesson to be learned from Ice and the Sky - beyond the obvious perils of ignoring the signs of climate change - it's of the importance of the research, drilling and testing that are behind the conclusions on offer.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, the most astonishing thing about The Club is not how it takes aim at the muddied history of the Catholic Church in Chile, but that it simultaneously, and just as effectively, serves as an allegory relating to a nation's political corruption.
It's a film that's determined to demystify an enigma, but the sobering reality is that the most enlightening way into the mind of this artist is doubtlessly to listen to his records.
Simply enchanting.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Pacy, thought-provoking entertainment. Not perfect, but well worth the admission.

You might be rather surprised at just how likeable the bubblegum teen romance of Hannah Montana: The Movie actually is. And this is due in no small part to the superior comic acting chops of amiable bow-legged songbird, Miley Cyrus.
As single joke movies go, this droll, happy-go-lucky miniature from writer/director/actor Gianni Di Gregorio is easily one of the better ones.
A lean, empathetic and dramatically credible portrait of desperation and desire on the cider-splashed streets of adolescence.
The most interesting aspect of Capitalism is a strain of melancholic nostalgia that runs through its latter segments

From its title downwards, this uninspiring French dramady embraces cliché at every turn, relying on simplistic humour, obvious emotional cues and performances straight out of Albert Square to tell its story.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: So here it is: an essay film it's okay to like.
A hit and miss affair, but an admirably eccentric one.
A baffling film. Not just the narrative, but the motives behind making it.
Sags in the final third, but the impeccable craftsmanship keeps matters afloat.
One for the history books.
It doesn't show a director evolving, just one happy to do what he does well.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A cucumber-cool satire which views the poetry and passion of spiritual faith through a prism of rigid bureaucracy and ruthless logic.
Shot and acted on an adrenaline rush, Harsh Times has the free structure and intensity of a true indie film, but is sometimes just a little off-balance.
A must for those who like their crime capers cool and elegant.
It opens the audience's ears to the diversity and vitality of Istanbul's music scene but, as a documentary, it lacks the mainstream appeal of Buena Vista Social Club.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It plays a risky game, switching tone from domestic drama to political point-making to broad comedy to sticky sentiment in a matter of moments, rounding everything off with a perfect ending that will make grown men weep.
Solidly entertaining without being spectacular.
Bold stylistic decisions reinforce the themes of the narrative, while a strong story and convincing performances prove equal to the task of carrying such an extended running time.

Placing his lunatic ensemble of social misfits into a series of episodic story blocks with faultless timing, the director evocatively captures the look, mood, sounds and, most of all, the eccentric attitudes of this alien realm.
After a healthy start, pretentiousness lets down a promising premise, and the film just runs out of ticker.
movie_title: The Story of Marie and Julien (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Evie is a character in search of a film that's strong enough to contain her -- and sadly this isn't it.
A remarkable debut from Ray that though slow is extremely absorbing.
The songs and set pieces are still fresh and infectious and most of the child cast are mesmerisingly good. I defy anyone not to be caught up in the charm and nostalgia.
One of the more entertaining and thought-provoking Spike Lee Joints in a long while.
No amount of skate tricks or avalanche-dodging ski stunts will win us over if the characters have had their charisma surgically removed.
Go see The French Connection instead.
Hartnett never allows him to become a hissable villain, keeping Hugo shy of our sympathies, yet his every move is utterly believable.
Ambitious in structure and casting, it packs a lot into its screen time. Quality craftsmanship for a discerning crowd.
Arnold has his place on the small screen, but here his attempts to save his neighbourhood from corporate takeover seem overextended.
[Loach] manages to reach beyond social debate to touch you on an emotional level.
Malkovich is perhaps the best, most chillingly precise Ripley to date.
British urban crime movie that is several cuts above the rest.
An intelligent and witty experience that's thematically rich and often downright funny.
The worst film ever made: a film about idiots, made by idiots, for idiots.
Even in its most violent moments, 16 Years Of Alcohol is suffused with visual poetry.

Oscar nominations it richly deserves, not least for Michael Caine, whose performance as an English reporter goaded out of his comfortable, opium-clouded, ex-pat lifestyle ranks among the very best of his career.
Not up there with the very top echelon of Disney classics, but Pinocchio will still work its magic on younger viewers.
A gripping tale of eroticism and sexual fantasy that keeps grips with its taught atmosphere and passionate performances.
Offers a more imaginatively colourful world than almost every other children's film out there.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Broomfield turns his distinctive 'blundering' style into something that could really help clear up the case.
Story and style both keep viewers on their toes.
Sad and beautiful, sly and funny, clever and controversial.
A mini-masterpiece that marks the arrival of brave new talents in Gyllenhaal and Kelly. Cult glory beckons.
One of the year's best, with crossover potential along the lines of Cyrano De Bergerac and Il Postino. Given its quirky heart, it might well surpass them all.
This is a two-star movie dragged down a star because of its unrepentant racism.
A breathtaking story told in breathtaking style.

movie_review_blurb: An uplifting film that cemented the reputation of its star.
Travelogue, biography, tender portrait of friendship -- the film is strong in all these areas, but excels in fusing them into an affecting whole.

Utilising the cheapest-looking animation ever to grace a cinema screen, this Cartoon Network spin-off will only appeal to a fraction of pre-teen girls.
Plot holes and a mixed tone lessen the impact but Gordon-Levitt holds it together with a strong lead performance.
It may have slipped from an X rating to a 12A but this is still a potent adaptation of Bran Stoker's eternal monster.

After recent disappointments Sir Dickie Attenborough is back on better, albeit old-fashioned, form.
The songs and magic are still fresh, even if it isn't quite knowing enough, perhaps, for today's young audiences.
Visually striking early telling of the German folktale.
Welles genius behind the camera brings one of the Bard's darkest plays to life.

movie_review_blurb: Surreal and wonderful in a way not often seen from Europe.
Karl Freund's ground-breaking and historically important cinematography can still take the breath away.

A wonderful salute to British decency and a touching portrait of a friendship that bridges national boundaries.

movie_review_blurb: Humanist film-making at its best.
Sentimental but sincere.

A poignant reflection on what it means to be alive and, visually, a true cinematic experience.

An accomplished masterpiece, with excellent performances and rarely bettered direction.

Delightfully upbeat, it will send you back out onto the street grinning from ear to ear.
An ambitious, bloody and engrossing work.

An opportunity frustratingly squandered, but one which still makes for fascinating viewing thanks to Castro's natural charisma. Errol Morris would have nailed it.
Scarily awful -- this spoof horror franchise needs a stake driven through its heart, and quick...
While not quite the equal of the novel, it's more complex, emotionally-charged and better acted than the average Hollywood thriller.
Enjoy it as a simple horror film. Don't try and make it more than that.

... a moving, enlightening tale of recent times.
Just because you shoot semi-improvised scenes in black-and-white doesn't mean you're the new Jim Jarmusch.

A connoisseur's delight: two hours of short films celebrating the most romantic city in the world.
A screen-acting showcase by a man whose best days, many thought, were behind him. There's life in the old dog yet.
The Recursion Theorem is a fantastic tale of a man caught in a supernatural puzzle. In many ways, Sledge creates a faithful homage to The Twilight Zone.
Easy Living is a character study of a real-life Peter Pan, who can't quite find the doorway into adulthood.

Sit back and enjoy the roller-coaster ride known as Thor: Ragnarok. Do yourself a favor and see it in a packed theater. If you can't do that, then head right to the couch and pop open your favorite beer and have fun.
Wait For Your Laugh does what a biographical documentary needs to do-document the life of an important person for the sake of posterity.
Never Let Go is the female version of Taken.
Creatives have stories to tell. This is Noël Wells' story to tell. And good storytelling like Mr. Roosevelt is why we watch independent films. It's a good story and a good start for Wells.
Eddie is an amusing short, that takes a light comedic look at the effects of solitude and boredom on our psyche.
In Dealt, director Luke Koren masterfully tells the story of a man, who through hard work and discipline overcame his disability.
The film is beautiful to look at. The film is hand-drawn, and the outdoor settings and backdrops are breathtaking. A Silent Voice is a true piece of art.

I admired the attempt to recreate 60s LA on an independent film budget. Shots, locations, and sets gave the feel of a story of the past. Unfortunately, the slow pace and melodramatic dialogue gave the film a made-for-television vibe.
Payv Raz's Clarity takes us on an emotional roller coaster of tragedy, lies and bad acting.
The gimmick of Watch The Sunset succeeds in elevating a standard story of drugs, family, and redemption and rarely feels forced.

No matter where you fall on the economic spectrum, John Paul's story is the inspiration for everyone to give.

I loved watching Holy Air because it's different. Srour takes values we share as human beings like love, family, and duty and then places in a different context like any good comedy should do.

I liked Killing Gunther enough to recommend it. Look, comedies are meant to make you laugh. I have a low threshold for silliness, and I am a fan of the cast.
Unfortunately, the film's situation and dialogue fail to push A Bad Idea Gone Wrong successfully across the finish line. It's situation just doesn't feel dangerous enough.
What makes Knife Skills amazing is its goal of rehabilitation. It's about forgiveness, offering hope and giving second chances.
The ending reveal is poignant, haunting and real. Films should be judged alone on the final product. My Nephew Emmett is a fantastic film.

Watu Wote is an inspirational story of solidarity based not on identity, race, or religion, but by the undeniable fact that we're all human beings.

The fun of a mystery is solving the crime based on the clues presented, but the clues don't necessarily lead to the conclusion. It feels like we're just stumbling over the final reveal. Despite these complaints, Crooked House is worth watching.
The visuals of Coco are amazing from the bridge of flowers to the world of the dead. It's clear that Pixar took great care in getting Latin culture perfect.
All I can do is be honest. Spent is a really bad movie.

Simply put, this is a bad, bad film, this summer's answer to last summer's The League of Extraordinary Gentleman.

What's perhaps most moving in Waiting for August, a quiet film of weight and joy, is its sense of desperate normalcy.

Raw and upsetting ...

The millionth movie about an American having adventures abroad and then finding himself, or whatever. If that was the point, maybe the movie's actually brilliant.

The fights Virunga documents couldn't feel more urgent. This is one of the year's most compelling and important films.

Harrowing, thrilling, and all-around well-reported ...
A gentle soul-stirrer ...
Offers just what the title promises, an involving and affectionate study of Caroll Spinney, whose Sesame Street bird we've all been following for almost half a century now.

Joyous yet dispiriting ...

An uncommonly well-made thriller.

A good-hearted kids' drama whose earnestness and surprising moral complexity put other sunny-weepy sea-mammal flicks to shame.

Vital and vigorous even when its characters feel scraped of vigor/vitality, Philippe Garrel's latest finds boho Parisians facing the ends of marriages, affairs, and the feasibility of bohemian existence itself.

The doc is often terrific fun. But it is a work of observation and advocacy rather than journalism.

An urgent, illuminating dive into the headwaters of second-wave feminism, the movement that - no matter what its detractors insist - has given us the world in which we live.
The rare truthful and beautiful film about the rock 'n' roll life.

movie_review_blurb: Even if, like me, you agree with the points that it's fumbling toward, The True Cost will likely read as dopey and insulting ...
Anne Fontaine's Flaubert-inspired meta-pleasure Gemma Bovery takes as its subject the act of watching the lives around us - and of wishing those lives were literature.

The film is engaging, propulsive, cut with rare brio, chockablock with consummate tough-guy business.

[A] cynical, poisonous, deeply stupid film ...
[It] has gone from the exemplar of what expressive narrative filmmaking could be to something more elegiac: This is what it now rarely even dares aspire to.
A documentary that asks many comics big questions about the dispositions of comics - but doesn't often enough put anyone off balance, the audience included.
Unfriended is the one movie from 2015 you'll always be able to look back at and feel something of what life was like back when, even if you're not a cyberbullying white teen.

What they find is scarier than what their predecessors turned up in The Thing and The Thing From Another World, and they explain it with such clarity and force you might feel bad for wishing the movie would let you Zen out to the landscape more often.
An adaptation of a Steven Millhauser short story, Sisterhood drags out to feature length a mystery that's best handled in just a couple pages.
The film plays too safe with its narrative. Fortunately, like its characters, it's most daring when it's in motion.
The movie's messy. But it's funny, pungent, and sometimes affecting.

It's sometimes a little prim, but its suspense scenes are well executed, and Chopra composes complex, arresting images full of reflections and natural split-screen effects that I only wish were illustrative of some meaning.
Cameron Crowe writes movies like he's calling us in eighth grade with his heart on fire.

The ending's a touch too cute, but the best scenes here stand as potent, empathetic, well-observed broadsides against fundamentalism.

movie_review_blurb: I'm thankful for the chance to meet Hall.
Detestable even as it's charming and ingratiating.

Each shot in an Andersson film is part diorama, part theatrical performance, part moviemaking the way Thomas Edison did it: Build a set, plant a camera, and stage highly orchestrated comedy and tragedy.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

A picture whose emphasis feels off from the start.

Even though the film is Marvel's crowning aesthetic triumph, even though all four of its stars have their game faces on and act their hearts out, even though it's got great humor and spirit, Doctor Strange isn't close to being Marvel's best movie.
It's alluring when it isn't trying so damn hard to convince you it's sexy.
It offers up a peculiar amalgam that's part commencement speech, part policy analysis, and part gentle GOP ribbing.
Chris Terrio's feature film debut offers few surprises -- one readily spots the big twist early on, perhaps because it's so deftly set up--but ultimately fulfills the expectations of the viewer.
Seems to go in a dozen directions at once but ties up in the final reel into a tight, cohesive and enjoyable whole.
Each vignette is fine, as far as it goes, but none go very far.
Though the audience always remains at a distance, both physical and emotional, from Yumiko, her sense of loss and her inner journey are made vivid by purely filmic means.

The film's structure and resolute lack of closure deeply subvert American expectations of how a movie should be, how a movie should work and how a story is told. But it's worth a look, however quizzical.
A work of great emotional depth and impact.
Frank Vs. God makes solid arguments for and against the effectiveness of religion and the existence of god, but, like reality, doesn't offer any life-changing answers.
The Sabbatical exemplifies the power of good storytelling over spectacle cinema.
Actor Victor Almanzar makes his screenwriting debut with the gritty, visceral, and sobering 11:55.
