With nuance and an introspective eye, Almereyda creates a beautifully bleak, hypnagogic world in Marjorie Prime that allows its pensive themes to flourish.
Good Time is a fast-paced, oscillation of raw emotion and manic suspense that plays directly to Pattinson's continually emerging thespian strengths.
With an A-list cast set against the Austin music scene, Malick has finally found a palatable balance between his visual and narrative poeticism.
In Suspiria, Argento's use of space, lighting, vivid colors, grandiose set pieces, and Goblin's score create a masterclass in suspense and subliminal terror.
Donnie Darko, the 1st cult classic of the 21st century, a masterclass in assiduous filmmaking, remains one of the most relevant, urgent and timely films of the last 50 years.
Final Portrait is filled with acute vigor, seamlessly-interwoven humor, impeccable historical accuracy, and superb acting that combine for another Tucci gem.
Brigsby Bear will surprise on several levels, including Mooney's strong writing and acting display, the film's intangible, transcendent tone and sheer originality.
The Mummy is a prime example of how a big studio can ruin a film by misdirecting its focus on spectacle over a cogent story, something that audiences have grown weary of.
Take Me doesn't beg the audience to think or force it to endure visually horrific imagery. Instead, it's a rather fresh take on the classic battle of the sexes trope.
Schrader delves into film music by merely acting as a fly on the wall, letting the masterminds speak for themselves, creating a non-intrusive film with a pulsating heartbeat.
By the end of Let Me Make You A Martyr, viewers will be antsy for the drawn-out story to finish so that they can leave this suffocating, vapid world.
movie_title: Let Me Make You a Martyr (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As choppy and dragging as it may be at times, and although it doesn't offer any revelations, The Wizard Of Lies is an intimate and sobering look at family betrayal.
The Dinner is a difficult film to watch, but it is worth seeing for Coogan's revelatory performance alone.
Once Upon A Time In Venice is clearly a film made by cinephiles, but the scattered subplots and underdeveloped characters combine for an overall misfire.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In a sense, Logan Noir is Mangold's own love letter to the fans of his Wolverine installments.
Table 19 is affable and empathetic, never aspiring to be more than it is in scope or scale.
The Blair brothers fail miserably at trying to give a heartbeat to Small Crimes. However, Coster-Waldau and the rest of the cast do their best with the source material they're given.
Though Win It All plays like a series of vignettes, Swanberg has become both grounded and creatively expanded as a result of Johnson's repeated collaboration.
Robespierre succeeds at making another candid, comedic portrayal of family dysfunction and difficult life transitions, this time from a multigenerational perspective.

Screenwriters Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick... fall short in creating realistic dialogue, scenarios, and frankly do a lazy job of trying to zero in on themes they want to focus on... They fail to add something fresh to what I see is an Alien knockoff.
Beneath the comedy in Band Aid, which turns into wonderfully executed slapstick at times, there is an intelligent and sincere commentary about societal gender expectations.
Brace yourselves, for Hounds of Love is the most terrifying torture porn film since the genre's inception.
Coogan and Brydon bare their truest selves in The Trip To Spain, resulting in an emotional and bitingly honest chord that rings mellifluous with the viewer.
Shot Caller is essential viewing, and one that will leave an unsettling but necessary, lasting impact on the viewer, providing them with plenty of philosophical ammo to play with.

Looking Glass wastes its talented cast on poor writing filled with cliché after cliché, an odd and uninviting artistic vision from the ground up, thinly developed characters, and an overabundance of narratives and plot devices.
The Music Of Silence lacks emotional weight, developed characters, a coherent linear story, and sufficient enough acting to make a passable biopic of a living legend.

The Cured is a fantastic zombie film with intelligent writing, precision direction, top-tier acting, and sincere sociopolitical themes and parallels that are essential in elevating horror films to something greater than just scares and gore.

Half Magic succeeds with the help of Graham's stellar writing, commendable direction, Beatriz, Kinsey, D'Elia, and the rest of the cast's adherence to Graham's comedic and dramatic vision, prescient themes, and three inspiring central characters.
A dual character study, All The Rage benefits from its celebrity testimonies, candid interviews with Dr. Sarno, and Galinsky's efficiency of substantiation.

Abe & Phil's Last Poker Game boasts a trio of fantastic performances, particularly from Sorvino and Landau in one of his finest turns in his final film, and contains just enough laughs and dramatic themes to overcome Weiner's rookie missteps.

Styler gives an admirable directorial debut despite a few minor missteps with Freak Show, bringing a career-making performance out of Alex Lawther and breathing life into Clifton and Rigazio's mediocre adaption of St. James' novel with tact.

Using acute, penetrating realism, a career-best performance from Wyle, air-tight writing incorporating pressing themes, and an unpredictable ending that will leave you speechless, Shot overwhelmingly succeeds as a film and a statement about our culture.

In finding the perfect lead in Jackman as Barnum, providing moving and invigorating musical numbers executed by a stellar secondary cast, impressive visuals, and covering timely topics, The Greatest Showman overcomes its narrative shortcomings.

With Burton's surreal illustrative ingenuity, Depp and Ryder's career-making performances, and a story filled with simplicity, complexity, and intangible wizardry that stands the test of time, Edward Scissorhands is one of the greatest films ever made.
With impeccable direction, engaging dialogue, consummate costume and makeup, and one of the best performances ever to grace the silver screen by Oldman, Darkest Hour is an overwhelming achievement.

Small Town Crime delivers the goods with a layered story, enthralling mystery, classic and evocative but innovative action, and a cast and crew devoted to a singular artistic vision, marking the rise of the Nelms brothers to the big leagues.

The Pirates Of Somalia stays true to its source material with a thoroughly insightful and honest exposé, it marks Peters' arrival as a cinematic virtuoso and yet another outstanding directorial effort from Oscar nominee Bryan Buckley.
With a story full of surprising twists and turns, a canvas of dazzling onscreen visuals, and a career-best performance from Middleditch, Entanglement succeeds on several tiers.
Realive is a science fiction drama with a brain, a scientifically altered one that hooks up to a power source beautifully.

Stronger does Jeff Bauman, the human being, justice by transposing his autobiography onto film in a purely unadulterated way thanks to Pollono, creating a resolute, powerful, and personal film that applies to the masses of the world, not just to Americans
Lucky marks one outstanding directorial debut for Carroll Lynch and two storytelling debuts for the ages in Sparks and Sumonja.
The Bachelors is a scarcity of a film, one that transcends several genres to create an affecting orotundity through its singular voice.
Walking Out is part father-son drama, part survival thriller, part coming-of-age yarn, and part uncompromising horror film.
Mayhem is a culmination of film, art, historical and current affairs references, genre juxtapositions, and effective stylized filmmaking.
Justice League is flawed...but its flaws are outweighed by its superb direction, decent dialogue, and excellent casting, acting, score, visual effects, and editing.
Heal is a documentary for everyone, whether one considers themselves an optimist, pessimist, believer in a higher power, atheist, or otherwise.
Regardless of some of the arguments that Cohen, Shenk, and Gore can't seem to zero in on, An Inconvenient Sequel is a documentary that everyone needs to see.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With verisimilitude, outstanding acting from its central and supporting cast, and a surprisingly gritty undertone beneath the melodrama and sentient multifaceted perspectives, Wonder succeeds in creating an honest portrayal of an uncommon life situation.
A gory, old-fashioned slice of schlock horror that, by successfully paying homage to one of the greats, puts many of its contemporaries in the shade.

Mother! suggests white patriarchy cannot be bargained with, it cannot be appeased, we cannot share space with it, and we cannot tactically choose the "right" battles-women need to take either back the house or burn it down.
[Director Ryan Coogler has] raised the bar even higher here. Visually, Black Panther is unlike any movie I've ever seen.
What trips it up more than questionable casting or even stunted dialogue is the epically confused narrative.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The most memorable French crime movie since La Haine.
As a portrait of recession-era America, and an examination of our humdrum working lives, I think it's unrivalled in its wit, its authenticity and its asperity.

It's a tough sell, for sure: a not-quite-comedy, not-quite-drama about a long-forgotten crime. But this is a rewarding film: slyly cynical about big business, American justice, and the men who represent both.
I enjoyed New Moon. It has occasional longeurs, for sure; it lurches from the sublime to the ridiculous (that's a cliché, but this film does just that); but it also has joyous moments.
A funny and involving new documentary.
Fish Tank is full of surprises, twisting and turning like a teenage girl trying to escape the clutches of an unwanted suitor.
Terminator Salvation opens on death row and proceeds agonisingly to an execution by lethal injection.

Milk is a fairly straightforward biopic distinguished by judicious use of contemporary newsreel, a tone at once impassioned and restrained - until the last few scenes, the film never resorts to emotional button-pushing.
[A] gorgeous, tightly written and entertaining film.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ingels's life comes across as exhausting, stressful and, at least until the last 30 minutes, lonely.
Words have not been invented to describe how bad it is.
It's a shame that within such beauty lies a pretty gloomy story, one that foolishly trusts the audience will get behind the whole stealing-a-baby concept. I didn't, and I got very bored.
With a minimal budget, [Babak] Anvari still manages to deliver a wholly unnerving universe.
Just like Flight 1549 itself, Sully starts off fine but doesn't quite seem to land exactly as planned.
There are certainly golden moments, but the pop culture references can be heavy-handed and the gags often feel too drawn-out.
It's no Jaws, but The Shallows is still a viciously, violently fun wave to ride.
You'd hope it would have matured like a fine vintage champagne, but unfortunately Absolutely Fabulous is one franchise that hasn't aged well.
It's a lot of fun, and allows each of the women to showcase their different comedic stylings whilst going up against "the man" (both literally and figuratively)
The BFG is visually stunning and laugh-out-loud funny at times, but lacks the beloved bite of other Dahl film adaptations.
Although uneven at times, The Legend of Tarzan lends an important historical context to the notorious character, which makes it worth a look.
Finding Dory, perhaps in a similar vein to this year's forward-thinking Zootopia, ventures into some interesting social territories where Finding Nemo did not.

Perhaps the greatest trick the Now You See Me franchise ever pulled was roping in so many acclaimed actors to prance around doing magic tricks and repeatedly saying things like "seeing is believing" without even the slightest of giggles.
There's just as many laughs as there are gunshots and Gosling's slapstick physicality and Crowe's wry dialogue bring some much-needed light to the dark.
Tickled will sucker-punch you right in the guts. A must-see.

Where to Invade Next is a departure from Moore's typically cynical, end-of-days vibe - this doco feels different, even optimistic. And although Moore does not present one cohesive solution, at least he's asking the questions in the first place.
It's lushly animated, genuinely hilarious at times and even comes with the all-important message about speaking up for what you believe in.
Captain America: Civil War turns The Avengers inside out, forcing conflict between the characters while managing to stage big action set pieces and even bigger jokes.
Combining fly-on-the-wall observations, talking heads and artistic cutaways, there is enough for everyone's tastes.
Taking its source material from a genuinely fascinating memoir, the screenplay squanders its potential by delivering a middling mash-up of comedy, thriller and war drama.
Do not be perturbed by the animation and animals, this movie is important, intellectual and hilarious.
it's a thrilling, heart-warming adventure through all walks of animal (and human) life.
Its whackiness and borderline fantasy might not be for everyone, but there's a universal, childlike appeal to the story that feels too powerful to deny.

London Has Fallen felt like a pitch-perfect parody of the hysteria around terror or a truly terrifying piece of xenophobic propaganda. If you choose to laugh at the irony of it, you'll probably have a great time.
Hail, Caesar! tentatively nibbles at any form of commentary, mostly choosing to soar high on an absurdly enjoyable flight of nostalgic fancy.
It's less sensual, more the cinematic equivalent of some tanked women at a hen's night hooting over a penis straw.
It was jarring, distracting and hilarious to watch, almost like being in a very sandy fun house.
Sure, script is hokey at times, and the film features a shockingly small amount of Meryl Streep considering her billing, but the historical event at its core transcends these finicky notes.
The problem with these new comedy sequels is that they feel uncomfortably forced. Sometimes it's better to not go back. Sometimes it's better to just leave things exactly where they are.
Nocturnal Animals traverses lithely across various fields of the human experience, from loneliness to revenge, trauma, to an increasingly disposable society.
What makes The Founder more than just your average Jobs-style mogul biopic is how it places Michael Keaton's Ray Kroc at the centre of the film, inviting him to be both the hero and the villain.
Told bluntly but with the utmost in dignity and empathy, this is a film that has the power to change minds and shift preconceived perceptions.
Not only is it a terrible film, but it is built upon the most disturbing premise I've encountered in the cinema in a long time.
For all its odd notes, The Fate of the Furious basically chugs along as reliably as my beloved old Toyota Starlet, with enough familiar talent and ludicrous action to get you from A to B.
Our plastic protagonist may not have Clooney's chest or the chiselled jaw of Affleck, but he's definitely the hero we need right now.
Feels like it could be the death knell of the middling monarch movie genre altogether.
A nuanced portrait of power, gender and crushing small town sadness.
It's definitely the kind of old-school screwball comedy that makes you do a weird half smile like a drunk person.
You're in for some big, dumb, freaky fun.
Colossal is an odd film that may feel disorienting to some, but it's also a totally original conceit that dares to tackle a little thing in a gigantic way.
You might not lose your lunch, but you'll probably find something to chew over.
It's slick, enjoyably brutal and beautiful but, just like its protagonist, feels like it lost a little bit of soul somewhere along the way.
Everything else remains entirely the same out of either laziness or a fear of redneck audiences screaming at the changing world around them.
There are large impressive stunts, pratfalls and chaos, but seldom does Office Christmas Party ever actually shock or delight in the way that it thinks it does.

You don't need to like superheroes to enjoy this film, you just need to know that it will leave you welling up with tears and clutching your loved ones, which is a momentous achievement for any blockbuster indeed.
It flits between hallucinatory animation and 'reality', giving small moments of relief and attempting to anchor the story in a desolate Los Angeles.
It's a visually exquisite film, a father-daughter love story and a must-see feminist fable for the whole family.
Sure, Gary and the Pacific has enough in it to enjoy, but you can't help but sense at times that it is simply treading safe waters instead of taking the plunge.

There are many hilarious gags and performances (the TV show within the film is spectacular), but the film is also full of devastatingly sad moments of loneliness that will leave you feeling like a wooden Pinocchio.
Jackie is a mesmerising tour de force, as brutal as it is gentle and as jaw-droppingly gorgeous as it is bleak.
A particularly painful scene featuring a loud scratchy quill on loud scratchy parchment made my hair and teeth feel very very loose. I think that's what J.L.G wanted, though.
Manchester by the Sea is a quiet, contemplative film that blends the most extreme depths of mourning with lashings of playful humour and explosions of anger.
In a twist as sharp as the ending to each of his cinematic creations, M. Night Shyamalan returns to form with film that actually isn't terrible in Split.

Fences is a poignant domestic drama that takes its time and seldom cuts corners, the dialogue sprawling and spiking in a way that seems much better suited to the stage than what we are used to seeing on the snackable big screen.
Cinematic experiences like this don't come around very often, where you bear witness to a vision that feels both completely fresh, and as universal and deeply personal as film-making can get.

T2 is enjoyable enough as a film, and I am sure that those who Trainspotting resonated most with will slip back into the world gleefully, as into an old pair of slippers. But as a sequel to an era-defining pop culture touchstone, it falls a little flat.
With sparse dialogue, the film hinges on an incredible performance from Rinko Kikuchi as office-girl outsider Kumiko, who can hurt your heart with just a little flick of her eye.
There's no denying the pair's dazzling old Hollywood star power is well-suited to a film clearly in love with the era.
[Sing is] taking the delightful animal world of Zootopia, stripping it of its complex moral teachings, and chucking in a whole lot of absolute pop bangers to boot.
Lion is an astounding, all-encompassing story of hope, determination and dumb luck that will leave you both crying like a baby and clapping like a seal once the credits roll.
Rings is cursed from the outset, doomed by the same technology in which the franchise once thrived.
Director Tobias Tobbell keeps the tone taut, but is let down by over-familiar ground, underdeveloped ciphers and a payoff that's not half as clever as it thinks it is.
Sometimes more Wikipedia bio than memoir.
It's a fun routine, but you already know all the steps.
The sets are tight and stagey, every corner is decorated with baroque lushness, every shot framed by a velvet curtain or silvery branch. And the dialogue isn't caged in by any attempts at naturalism.
Putting a spin on classic fairy tales is nothing new, and unfortunately that's just what the Shrek-lite animated feature Happily N'Ever After brings to the big screen.
...Takes an already derivative plot and guts it like so many Urgals.
Director Luc Besson admits he knew nothing about animation before he started this project, and it shows.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The real problem with Epic Movie is that while it does a decent job imitating films, it never bothers to make fun of or have fun with them.
Equally as perplexing as its lack of perspective is the film's overall shortage of information.
Aside from uncensored profanity and unpixelated nudity, the Reno 911!: Miami never really stretches its legs, and instead often feels more like a stretched-out half-hour episode.
A wonderfully heart-wrenching love story for tweens, teens, and even adults who fondly remember when a friendship could be ignited by a gesture as simple as offering a stick of Juicy Fruit.
Though it never completely catches fire, there's enough earnestness and warmth that makes it a welcome alternative in a family film arena dominated by computer animation and associated toy lines.
While not much of a detective story, [director] Robinson's period film does provide a captivating look at the dynamics that turn Fernandez and Beck into serial killers.
It's a rich portrait made all the more worrying by apparently being based on actual events.
The relationship between the two men isn't the only romance in the film, as the camera slowly falls in love with rural Yorkshire.
From A to B is a product of its culture for better and worse.
Speed Sisters is a relatively short documentary about a fascinating subject that receives a disappointingly shallow treatment.
There is certainly some entertainment value to be had here, but a movie that lacks earnestness has a licence to be fun; Ritchie never once properly takes that chance.
Directed by Naji Abu Nowar in his feature debut and coscripted by Bassel Ghandour, Theeb boasts an easy confidence and a striking sense of logic.
Allen's creative freedom is something to be celebrated, but its benefits aren't always passed along to the viewing public.
We Are Your Friends is a movie that examines a subculture and takes some effort to explain what it's all about, but not once does it try to make you care about anything that happens on screen.
Dope is an effective celebration of friendship, sculpted hair and sweet bike rides.
Fox has thrown $122 million at the screen for 100 minutes of garbage, and none of it has stuck.
Mostly it's a nice character study -- albeit one that may have chosen the wrong character to focus on.
She's Funny That Way is an oddity that feels like a crowd pleaser but ultimately plays to a very small room.
Vacation throws away any of the vestiges of family friendliness that characterised the franchise to date, and discards any warmth that we may have been able to feel for the Griswolds in the process.
A sensitive and well shot film with only a single stumbling block, Last Cab to Darwin deserves to become an Australian institution in itself.
13 Minutes is a sort of biopic that admires its subject's cause and his conduct under incarceration but never manages to make the man's life anything approaching cinematic.
Mr. Holmes is slight, sustained by the charisma of its leads and the sunny English countryside.
Though The Gift is a relatively small film, it carries with it a strong emotional impact, and augurs well for Edgerton's future on every side of the camera.
Paper Towns is yet another teen movie about a colourless boy who defines himself by a girl he'll never allow himself to know.
Women He's Undressed is a documentary that succeeds, occasionally against its director's instincts.
What do you do if you have a confounding philosophical idea, but you're not quite sure to handle it? You add flamethrowers to your story. Lots of flamethrowers.
A refreshing celebration of the non-toxic variety of masculinity, Magic Mike XXL hits every mark that it aims for. This is the America the world dreams about.
Ant-Man is a neat package, that comfortably wears its connection to the Marvel Cinematic Universe without labouring the point.
Comic book films cannot survive on action or spectacle alone, so it is some comfort to know that The Wolverine has a relatively solid script.
This movie is marking time for bigger things, a constant fear in the lead-up to another Avengers outing, but it's fun and entertaining enough to justify the time spent watching it.
X-Men: Days of Future Past is not only an enjoyable comic book film, it serves as an apologia for the messes of X-Men: The Last Stand and X-Men Origins: Wolverine.
Amy may not be the definitive version of Amy Winehouse's life, but it feels like it is. In documentary, that's what counts.
Kick-Ass 2 has nothing to say, and it says it in the most vulgar way possible.
With particular attention paid to the intricacies of time travel, quantum and, most important of all, humanity, it's the most valid entry in the Terminator series since 1991.
Trainwreck has an undeniably funny script, but much of its humour is in both line delivery and facial expressions.
Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials is a movie that combines the weaknesses of the book it burst forth from with a whole new set of problems of its own.
A disaster movie more about solutions than problems, The Martian is Matt Damon's most successful extraterrestrial foray to date.
Joe Wright's Pan is an incredibly derivative new take on a classic character -- but it's not all bad.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes works precisely because it believes in itself and will brook no arguments.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is not a pretty movie, despite its high budget.
This Mediterranean holiday piece has many elements that conspire towards greatness, but its core is as empty as a drained swimming pool.
Neither well acted, scripted or designed, and completely lacking in brand appeal, Gods of Egypt is an expensive blockbuster targeted at no one in particular.
10 Cloverfield Lane is a small movie that takes big risks, and all of them pay off.
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a profoundly dissatisfying film.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though it will undoubtedly mean more to people somewhat intimately familiar with Apple's history, Steve Jobs is a nevertheless affecting piece of cinema that never attempts to canonise its subject matter.
Dirty Grandpa has a couple of jokes that work and live up to its name, and Aubrey Plaza was beamed into it from another planet but in every other way it is an abject failure.

Room has the combined talents of Larson, Allen and Tremblay behind it, but it boasts a banality that robs it of the punch that it needs. This is low impact cinema, but not entirely without its merits.
Carol is a snow globe of a movie: an ornate and delicate piece, frozen in time. Lavishly designed and performed with precision, it's a love story that deserves to endure.
The Revenant is accomplished, but it is not entertainment.
With its high count of profanity, blood spatter, and spilled jelly beans, The Hateful Eight is a huge work crammed into 250 pounds of celluloid, bursting to be seen.
Pixels calms down and doesn't contain a lot of internal logic, but with Monaghan and Dinklage to do the heavy lifting, it manages to stay afloat.
Neither compellingly made or told, Suffragette has the burden of prestige without the substance to back it up.

Perhaps a largely inert movie about two older men hanging out in a Swiss luxury spa would have been a hard sell otherwise, but Youth has the capacity to pleasantly surprise its audience -- and it does so repeatedly.
It's not just a great piece of science fiction, or a great piece of cinema: it's a new hope.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With multiple jokes that feel like complete justifications for the film in themselves, The Night Before could well become the vulgar Christmas classic the world deserves.

In the Heart of the Sea is a straightforward recount of the story that inspired Moby-Dick, embroidered by Howard's eye for romantic composition and anchored by a surprisingly affecting expository turn from Brendan Gleeson.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Program has some fascinating character notes to it, but it's mostly an inconsistently stylised portrait of a monster.
Creed is a movie that plays to type and presses a lot of emotional buttons, and it does it so well that you just might forget to rail against formula and cheer for the underdog once more.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 could easily have been rolled together with Part 1, but it hasn't turned out too poorly.

SPECTRE is a return to the halcyon days of the more brazen Bonds; compounded with today's marginally more enlightened attitudes towards women, the Craig entries have synthesised into a finely tuned machine.
At its best, Midnight Diner is a warm, feel good piece; at its worst, it's just ever so slightly stuffy. There's enough here to justify asking for seconds.
Man Up would have been stronger all around if, when it eliminated the element of chance, it gave a stronger voice to its actual lead instead of rendering her a shrinking violet.
It is a stylish film, and it manages to avoid the pitfalls of sentiment through its utilisation of an almost unfeasibly dark heart and wicked sense of humour that trends dangerously close to cruel.

Kurzel's Macbeth is definitely not to every taste, solidifying its tragedy almost into a mire for the viewer to wade through, but it's definitely a worthy and valid interpretation of one of theatre's most famous and bloody kings.

While there is a story -- satisfactorily told and resolved -- Joy is dedicated to its craft. Joy continues the streak that Russell and Lawrence have going, though they are seemingly becoming less accessible with each iteration.
Cameron Crowe may have been aiming for something in Aloha, but somewhere along the way he forgot to make a film.
It's almost guaranteed to make undemanding fans of the first smile, but it is overall an empty experience.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Emotionally mature, genuinely funny, beautifully animated, and with a message that never feels preachy, Inside Out is one of Pixar's finest efforts to date.

The Divergent Series: Insurgent is the logical successor to The Hunger Games, in that it features a female lead in a dystopian future America. It would be helpful if The Divergent Series: Insurgent was a good film.
This combination of the earnest with the ridiculous is exactly how Fast & Furious draws you in.
Strikes a delicate balance between social commentary, show business satire, general vulgarity and legitimate sweetness.
This is perhaps Marc-Vallée's least showy and most balanced film, handling despair, hope and, in one of the film's most memorable scenes, terror in unexpectedly subtle ways.
Better than it has any right to be.
It's so intricately designed, so expensive looking and so obviously inaccessible to general audiences that its very existence is a miracle.
Focus is a movie with an arbitrary title, but full commitment from its cast.
A loving homage to spy movies that stands as a film in its own right, Kingsman draws its influences from all the right places and, most importantly, is entertaining.
Despite its miniscule degree of ambiguity, the goal and outcomes of American Sniper are clear: a great man done a great thing for a great country.
Some movies have to be made, have to be seen, and no other consideration needs to be entered into.

Ultimately, Chef is a comfort food film. There's room in this world for all sorts movies, and not all of them have to be challenging. There's nothing difficult about Chef, but that doesn't stop it from being worth the tasting.
It's a near perfect closed loop of a film: fun, well-conceived and never afraid to treat death with both the reverence and contempt that it deserves.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The best thing about Love Is Strange is its title.

As a character study, Gloria is a rare pleasure. There's no quiet heroism in just living day to day, but there's definitely something admirable in bringing such a fully formed woman to the screen, naked and free to dance all she wants.

Once again, Anderson has managed to make an affecting, funny movie; it may be more melancholy than most, but bittersweet love is love nonetheless, and The Grand Budapest Hotel is worth visiting multiple times.
Berger plays Blancanieves like a game, very carefully monitoring the mood and heightening it or lowering it as needs be.
Disney does two things pretty well: princesses and musicals. Frozen has both of these traits in force.
The Little Death is just a mostly laughless tour of unlikeable, depressive suburbanites.
Over the top by design, Gone Girl is delightfully lurid without ever feeling exploitative.
Besson has taken a silly concept and elevated it to a level that can best be described as insane poetry.
Good intentions are not enough to make it work on any of the levels it was designed to, and there's only so much of Winslet and Brolin looking sad that you can substitute for substance.
It is not cheerful, hopeful, or profound: it just is.
[That Awkard Moment] has nothing particularly special about it, but it's pleasant, it's funny, and it features young and pretty people learning how to be sensible adults.
Feste is not exactly a masterful button pusher, but she has a clear goal in mind and she achieves it admirably.
There are only so many spats that you can sit through before you realise it's difficult to care for the outcome, no matter how twisted it is.

The Rocket was designed as a crowd pleaser, and it does that: it combines the danger of the unknown with the safety of feel-good narrative expectations for film festival success, and perhaps even general release victory.

[The Lego Movie hits] the sweet spot between adults who grew up with Lego and children who love Lego, and carefully ignoring the irony of such an overtly branded indictment of corporate strangulation of creativity.
Gibney, despite his overly personal stamp, has presented as comprehensive a study of a deliberately secretive organisation as it possible at this point in time.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Shaun the Sheep Movie is truly remarkable all-ages film making.
Mildly amusing but always well acted.
Minions is an uninspired but more than marginally entertaining animation guaranteed to hit the mark for its key demographic.
An arresting piece of cinema.
Its strangeness and repetition may turn some away, but on both a technical and thematic level, it is a work to be celebrated.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There simply isn't enough dynamism to justify Sen's story. Australian movies have to work harder to secure audiences beyond those who go to them out of a sense of duty or worthiness; Mystery Road simply doesn't go that far.
A sweet character piece that almost comes across as effortless.
An inconsistent piece that runs from smug to infuriating.
In Slow West, John Maclean has proven himself an able filmmaker and talent handler.
Buoyed by the chemistry between its leads and the genuine feelings that they manage to convey, this is pastoral life as you like to see it on the screen.
Jurassic World is a movie that goes against the natural balance of the universe, but with the spirit of an eight year old boy: dinosaurs are cool, humans drool.
It's dumb, but at least it has a smile plastered on its face the whole way through.
Devoted fans of the series may find themselves comforted by the presence of old friends, but Vince and his troupe are very unlikely to make new ones.
It never knows quite what it wants to be, so it becomes everything and nothing all at once -- and none of it is done well.
Cinderella is nice and serviceable, with a refreshing lack of twists on its universally recognisable story.
A passion project without any passion evident in the final product, Tomorrowland is a 130-minute exercise in mystification.
The film is practically guaranteed to make the audience think -- and if that's not a cry to action, then what is?
While its 122 minutes are wildly inconsistent, there's likely to be something in Wild Tales for a curious filmgoer wondering what "the deal" with popular film in Argentina is.
Featuring a game cast more than committed to the faintly ridiculous material they've been given, Spy is likely to be one of the funniest films of 2015.
Ultimately, When Marnie Was There is a sweet film, worthy of the studio that produced it.
Binoche and Stewart anchor the stronger parts of Assayas' script, but nothing can save such an ultimately unpleasant and disingenuous piece of cinema.
A new entry in the Mad Max franchise every bit as unique as the first three, Mad Max: Fury Road is a welcome, exciting and surprising addition to the post-apocalyptic blockbuster genre.

Contemplative, untidy and more than a little bit depressing, Testament of Youth confounds expectations by conforming to the outline of history rather than a purely cinematic structure. It's all the better for it.

Marvel consistently puts out entertaining films which work towards a common goal - which is why it's mystifying that Avengers: Age of Ultron, nominally the best entry in phase two, is only mildly entertaining by comparison.
Perhaps not [Baumbach's] best film, but his easiest to embrace.
The Age of Adaline is a pearl of a film: intimate despite its century long scale, new and old at once, it's a small movie to discover and carry with you.

There is a baseline of filmmaking competence to The Gunman that rescues it from the gutter, but despite its star power it doesn't have a strong enough script or charismatic enough lead to carry it over the line into entertainment.
The Book of Life is a fun children's movie that is unlike most of what's being released in English-language markets for any demographic.

Of virtually no use as a socio-historical document, this is a movie that thrives on the appeal of its bright-eyed leads and the intervention of outrageous fortune. Fortunately for A Royal Night Out, that's enough.

Many modern comedies don't have much in the way of laughs or serviceable plots. That The Boss manages to land an admirable number of jokes while almost telling its story in a satisfactory manner feels like a triumph.
Strangerland works surprisingly well for a film that hinges on bad teenage poetry delivered in a completely disaffected tone.
Captain America: Civil War is overflowing with characters, taking old favourites, introducing new ones, and making them all work together in glorious harmony.

It may be less familiar to fans of either of the original works: something new may come from the old, and that's exciting; in the meantime It stands as a solid half-an-adaptation of a genre classic and a legitimate horror film.
Without overemphasising either the laughs or the emotion, The Big Sick is a romantic comedy that feels genuine.
There are many people willing to watch Charlize Theron commit violent acts; Atomic Blonde is one such vehicle that never fails to deliver in that regard.
War for the Planet of the Apes is overall a polished work that often explodes before your eyes into something truly radiant.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ill-conceived and clumsily executed, this is the sort of film that coasts on the names involved and is too indifferent to care if audiences actually like it.
As an examination of collective triumph and spirit it is a decisive victory.
Baby Driver is too much the soulless good boy doing bad things; what it lacks in substance it can't hope to make up for in style.
To watch The Beguiled is to see a director at the peak of her craft, in full control of her facilities.

It is a film that shows that cohesion of universe, a clear vision for a character, and a whole lot of money can make something of lasting value, and not just an eyesore that fizzles out after a single weekend.
Rough Night is a film of few surprises and fewer delights, a one-idea film that has difficulty filling out its overly generous 101 minutes.
Fun Mom Dinner is as the name suggests, and it's one of those gifts you're supposed to give yourself once a day.
Brigsby Bear is the sort of festival film that other festival films dream of being. Certainly it's quirky, but it's informed by an unassailable sincerity at its heart that dares you to accept it.
Patti Cake$ isn't exactly a rare film, but it is a fine addition to the pantheon of underdog movies.
The Other Side of Hope is a delicate balancing act that engages with the optimism deep within all of our souls, and it satisfies at a primal level.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With strong characterisation from a largely committed cast, coherent action and a rare confidence in its mise-en-scène, Wonder Woman is a comic book movie the way they should be done.
Baywatch is the latest in an increasingly long line of TV adaptation misfires, and it's one with some of the biggest names attached.
King Arthur: Legend of the Sword could have been one thing or the other -- one entertaining, one stock standard -- but it settles on an unhappy medium that is never tonally consistent.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is James Gunn taking his hundreds of millions of dollars and trying something more personal and heartfelt than one might have expected from a film whose ensemble include a trash panda, a twig and a woman with antennae protruding from her head.
Their Finest is not the kind of film on which wars are won, but it is exactly what a key demographic loves at the Australian box office. A calculated crowd-pleaser.
CHIPS is a vulgar and unthrilling comedy based on a forty-year-old franchise that no one looks particularly fondly on, its only claim to memorability being its repeated reference to analingus.

Ghost in the Shell is a movie that could have been a clean sweep, but the only elements that work are those that are directly taken from the 1995 and 2004 iterations, and even they are twisted into meaninglessness.
It's not great as a musical, but as a piece of dramatic fiction it has something to recommend it that pushes it across the line into satisfactory, even entertaining, cinema.
Power Rangers is a movie that is better than it probably should have been, but one that waits until it's almost entirely too late to strike the tone that it's most comfortable with.
The Eagle Huntress is an organic documentary made by a director who has an affinity for the serendipitous and an eye for on screen talent and scenery.

Well scripted, shot, and acted, there's very little not to recommend it: it streamlines a story without sacrificing complexity, and it is both entertaining and thoughtful while it's at it. It's enough to give you faith in the industry.
A Few Less Men is a throwback of a film, and not in a good way; it's messy rather than scrappy, and it just ends.
Despite a few hiccups of self-seriousness, there is a certain goofy tone that gets struck throughout that speaks of promise for the works to come.
Logan is a deliberately scuffed up work of comic adaptation art, and Jackman and Stewart could not have chosen to end their X careers on a higher note.
Sad to look at and joyless to watch, there's nothing on offer here for anyone but the least-demanding child.

American Assassin is a decently made tour of Europe, utilising easy target villains to maximise cheering from audiences willing to accept diplomacy down the barrel of a gun...as long as the gun is held by a nominally handsome American man.
This is a new children's classic with genuine substance and care evident in every frame.
Initiation Love is one third of a good movie, let down by 80 minutes of consistent frustration and inconsistent meeting of audience expectations.

La La La at Rock Bottom evaporates like so many lost memories. It's not an unpleasant film, but it's missing key elements that would have provided both narrative satisfaction and cohesive characterisation.
movie_title: La La La at Rock Bottom (Misono Universe) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lady Bird is a teen movie written by someone who remembers what it was like to be a teen, and one that understands that a character can be difficult without being irredeemable.
Black Panther gives you everything that you want from a Marvel movie, but it goes just that little bit further to sink its claws in and reward its unsuspecting audience.
Sweet Country is a landmark work of Australian cinema, even if it lacks commerciality: what it does offer is the diamond hardness of certainty. Few films are as sincere as this one.

Ultimately, if you want to hear Churchill talking about fighting them on the beaches, you could just watch Dunkirk again - Oldman's performance is literally transformative, but Darkest Hour is just another pedestrian biopic.
If Mildred is not a memorable character, the movie isn't being watched correctly.
Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a decent light-comedy adventure film that forgets much of what distinguished its predecessor, but stands on its own feet.
Downsizing would have been compromised if it had been designed to please everybody; Payne's undiluted vision is admirable, and you almost owe it to him to try it out.

If you can accept the excess, the weird humour, the entirely inessential subplot, and the fact that it could stand to end a scene earlier, then the series will continue to thrive in a galaxy far, far away.

If more writers and directors respected their audiences as King and Farnaby clearly does, the world's entertainment output would be significantly improved. Just like the bear himself, Paddington 2 makes the world a slightly better place.
The Golden Circle has the scent of missed potential.
Given the span of the film and the capriciousness of Hideyoshi Toyotomi, Flower and Sword has an awkward balance to it that one of Senko's creations would probably never suffer.

Midnight Diner 2 is a pleasant anthology film. It definitely feels like three episodes of a television series, and has only the slightest arc as its outer shell, but it's a nice experience, and if you want more, you can always go home and watch it.
The Disaster Artist is a movie that supplements an excellent film and an entertaining book while not quite hitting either's mark, but it is entertaining.

Cuteness and jauntiness can only go so far if there's no substance backing them up. My Uncle, a Japanese film with a name suggestive of a much loved, much older French film, is that insubstantial film.
ReLIFE is fairly standard manga-to-live-action adaptation fare that hits all of the right notes without exactly developing them.
Her Love Boils Bathwater very firmly belongs to its genre, but it innovates and expands on its hallmarks in such a way that it is able to sufficiently stand out.
movie_title: Her Love Boils Bathwater (Yu Wo Wakasuhodo No Atsui Ai) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mumon: Land Of Stealth is a movie that blinds its audience with flashily committed murders and then judges them for daring to enjoy the mayhem.
movie_title: Mumon: The Land Of Stealth (Shinobi No Kuni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Justice League is not the finest film in the DC Extended Universe - that honour is likely going to belong to Wonder Woman for a while yet - but it's much more in line with an actual movie than the first three outings.
Tori Girl is a fun and compact movie that combines the best of cycling with human-assisted flight.

Taking a character who has become embedded in the popular psyche and doing something slightly twisted with them is a good way of ensuring continuity while thumbing one's nose at the familiarity of contempt.
Perhaps the Coens could have made a better film of Suburbicon, but their friend Clooney has presented a collection of moments that never quite meld.

It's a refreshing piece of light horror that eschews gratuity for the sake of efficient storytelling that occasionally allows for both tongue-in-cheek and knife-in-gut and effectively stands astride multiple genre boundaries.

American Assassin is a decently made tour of Europe, utilising easy target villains to maximise cheering from audiences willing to accept diplomacy down the barrel of a gun... as long as the gun is held by a nominally handsome American man.
Wonder Wheel has a fundamentally solid concept and theme, but Allen's approach to heaping on miseries and neuroses becomes exhausting, and the film collapses under its own weight.
Miss Sloane is a taut "thriller", for lack of a better genre pigeonhole, brilliantly acted and intriguingly constructed, with only several baffling creative decisions bringing it slightly down.
Alien Covenant is often intriguing, but it feels more like an explanation engine than a movie.
A movie that is important, well-performed, and entertaining. It's a real crowd-pleaser, in other words.
Suicide Squad is a movie that contains moments of legitimate entertainment value that far outweigh any of its shortcomings.
While it doesn't need humour, it suffers from a terminal lack of charisma and imagination, leaving the world exactly as it was two hours before it started.
You could ask for more, but Star Trek Beyond is more than enough to be contented with.
Beckinsale is the perfect vessel for this dialogue, rattling off completely un-self aware statements and insults that border on the ridiculous with a straight face.
Being 17 is not a perfect film, but it is a remarkably measured examination of teenage infatuation and conflicting emotions.
With a great cast, soundtrack and a tender soul, Sing Street deserves to be an enduring antidote to nostalgia, a giant of modern Irish cinema.
Without memorable ghostly lore, there's the definite feel that there should be something more to Ghostbusters, but the four women and their dopey receptionist are enough to carry it over the line.
Maggie's Plan is a movie that flirts with greatness, but it frequently becomes hung up on its own artifice.
The BFG is dull and ugly. With no evidence of the charm of its source material, its screenwriter, or its director, it deserves to sink into obscurity.

It can be worth revisiting once youthful characters decades later, but often people get less interesting as they get older: T2 Trainspotting has less to say than its classic antecedent, and takes significantly more time to say it.
Here we have a celebration of male camaraderie and masculinity that comes at the expense of no one, a sex comedy that is both sexy and comedic.

A 77-minute heartfelt confection that is both tailored specifically to each pair it represents and demonstrates the strains of universality, truly making Mom and Me hit home with audiences that have ever had any sort of maternal relationships.
Even when it is at its most extreme, it feels painfully believable.
Land of Mine is not a conventionally entertaining movie, but it is very well made.

Buoyed by two committed performances, excellent sound design and a total lack of concern for discerning between the real and the illusive, this is a film to take away from the cinema with you. What you do with it after that, however, who knows.
This is accomplished debut film making with an important message with the promise of more great works to come.
With no answers, great actresses and few rewards, Certain Women is a tough but worthy trip.
A claustrophobic, up close and overly blunt piece, It's Only the End of the World doesn't even have the normal style that Dolan has to fall back on when his films aren't working on a thematic level.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Technical accomplishment pushes Money Monster over the line from a competent thriller on paper to a breathless 98 minutes that pop.
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows doesn't look good, has some truly awful dialogue and even the most forgiving Turtle fan may not be able to overlook its manifold shortcomings.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Films that are entertaining without having substance to them aren't uncommon, but Now You See Me 2 is the epitome of the empty flash.
[Alice Through the Looking Glass] takes echoes of familiar material and jams them together with limited success.
While its portrayal of the country that it calls home is not strictly authentic, the movie has an element of human truth that carries it over the line.
Despite its imperfections, Florence Foster Jenkins is a heartfelt piece of cinema, and its emotional core leaves the screen with you.

Bad Neighbours 2 is a legitimately funny comedy with a story, the minor miracle of modern filmmaking. It flirts with social commentary, takes advantage of most of its ensemble, and at least vaguely attempts to sequel-proof itself.
The outcome of Eddie the Eagle is apparent to anyone who's ever seen a sports movie before, but that really doesn't matter.
Catherine Frot is exceptional in the lead in the most literal sense of the word: she's the exception to an otherwise awful movie.
You can respect the sheer amount of effort that would have had to have gone into choreographing this film just so, but whether you'll enjoy it is another matter entirely.
We know that everyone involved in this movie has made superior material, so it's a shame to see Rogen and company slumming in their own filth.
It doesn't blaze a trail, and it's not terrible, but it's far from memorable.
Tickled is one of the strangest documentaries to see release in recent times, and while it offers some solutions it raises a lot of questions that cut to the heart of the human experience.

Devoid of flash, overflowing with excellent performances, and abundantly endowed with meaning -- to the point that subtext is practically non-existent -- Silence is the film Scorsese felt that he had to make.
Bad Moms is the American mom party movie that you didn't know you wanted, and while it's never more than a pleasant diversion, that's sometimes exactly what you want out of a comedy.
Gold is that strange beast: an okay story elevated by a performance richer than the material truly deserves.
More mood piece than standard narrative, more character sketch than study, Jackie is a fascinating film that rewards as it confounds.

As these weird vanity projects go, it's not a terrible one: there's a chance that, many years hence, adults will look upon it fondly as a relic of their motor-obsessed youth; it just has nothing to offer for anyone with an age in the double digits.
Being based on a video game does not automatically make your movie bad... a movie can be completely awful on its own terms, regardless of its source material, and Assassin's Creed is that movie.
Chazelle combines familiarity with wildly creative execution, proving that style is substance.

There's a sense of familiarity and a refreshing sense of being offered something we haven't quite seen before, and that Rogue One is actually entertaining about it makes the experience all the sweeter.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Office Christmas Party is a tightly wound and heavily calculated movie that possibly could have stood to be a bit looser than it turned out, but it is amiable enough.
When you've got a small unit as well realised as this one, you want to spend as much time with it as possible.
movie_title: The Mohican Comes Home (Mohican kokyô ni kaeru) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The audience leaves Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk on the same bearing as its characters: bemused, perhaps, but happy to have their company.
There's a lot here that would have made a more generic movie -- and a more easily enjoyable one -- if it had literally anything else to fill the void of its male lead's personality.
Creepy is the sort of film that will appeal to the sort of viewer who enjoys deeply unpleasant suburban nightmares with vaguely defined psychological underpinnings.
It's too late to call The Great Wall an expensive failure, but it's not likely to leave many satisfied viewers in its wake.
Incredibly well researched, written, directed and performed, I, Daniel Blake refuses to be ignored and spoken down to.
Compact enough to get its point across without throwing too many random elements at the screen, this is simple but relatively intelligent cinema.
Though there's nothing actively offensive about the execution of Storks, there's simply nothing compelling about it, either.

Westerns have enjoyed a small renaissance over the last decade. The Magnificent Seven may not be the best of them, but it's a respectable effort with a game cast helmed by a justifiably confident director.
The best that can be said for this film is that its third act diverges so significantly from the source material that it could easily get away with not becoming a series, a small mercy for us all.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Apart from being a guaranteed money-spinner, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is a wholly entertaining movie which, free from the burden of adaptation, is entirely its own thing.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Shin Godzilla is a particularly strong example of a uniquely Japanese genre: the battle of the bureaucrats -- the red tape rumble -- with special guest star giant beast from the deep.
This is a gritty film by someone unused to handling grit, and in some ways it shows, but ultimately Taylor has placed his faith in the hands of Blunt and been rewarded.
Masterminds has more joys than your average anaemic comedy, but none of them justify the time invested in going to the cinema.
With a charismatic lead and almost infinite potential for future set pieces, it's nice to think that we could have another blockbusting dynamo on our hands.
Neither conventionally well-made nor avant-garde enough, The Accountant is caught in a limbo where it lacks the appeal to satisfy either general or niche audiences.
If you want to think about intelligent life instead of blowing it up, Arrival may be the movie for you.
Inferno is a two-hour travelogue that ultimately goes nowhere.
From the not-so-happy birthday that opens the film ... up to the harrowing final revelation, Miss Violence fulfils the grisly promise of its title.
Jaoui's debt to Woody Allen is more glaring than ever: some of the characters are just a bundle of neuroses.
movie_title: Au bout du conte (Under the Rainbow) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The offbeat comedy threatens to suffocate the film, seeping into every scene and nipping any attempts at characterisation or emotional resonance in the bud.
Every social group is reduced to the crudest cliché.
yrical, satirical and hugely entertaining, it deserves a wider audience. Hopefully, with this welcome re-release, it will find one.
'Jauja' is a film to make you wonder.
This is a bold and unusual film, which takes material that will be unfamiliar to most viewers and interprets it with more inventiveness than they will be used to.
Thoughtful, nuanced and fun, Sanctuary subverts received ideas about disability in its very approach to filmmaking.
Plays out as a wistful, slow-burning romance, underscored with a streak of social satire and animated in exquisitely subtle pastels and watercolours.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is that rarest of features that shows a deep understanding of people, truly cinematic storytelling technique and brilliantly choreographed fight and chase scenes.
It's peak mumblecore with some big stars getting in on the action. And it's completely empty.
While the quasi-intellectual banter is fun, I just can't get too excited about whether or not two people I do not like are going to fulfill their terrible dreams.
It'll win you over in the first few minutes with an impressively innovative car-chase scene that includes one of the drivers playing dead at the wheel.
It's not sappy. It's a tight action movie focused on talented people working together for the good (or harm? You have no idea!) of the world.
The strongest part of Thorpe's film is how he blends his personal story with the larger issue.
When a movie starts with a dumb idea and it's badly executed, you can't be that disappointed. It's not a big waste. But when a great concept gets bungled, it feels like a loss.
If you're up for bro-ing down, have I got a movie for you.
I'm not big into awkward comedy, but The Overnight is so deft and surprising that I almost enjoyed the feeling.
It's got a lot of heart, more than you'd expect from a comedy and less than you'd expect from a drama. That genre switching is its main failing, though.
It makes a dusty genre feel distinctly modern.
It's sad. Crushingly, relentlessly sad. And absolutely brilliant.
Every single prop, costume and character looks insanely cool, like a world war erupted at Burning Man.
It tells the story in a powerful and uncomplicated way.

At least Arnold is still fun. It was a brilliant move in the first place; here's an actor incapable of sounding human, so let him play a robot and don't give him many lines. That trick still works. But the other characters, not so much.
As we begin Maze Runner 2: Still Runnin', these rapscallions have escaped the maze and they can finally stop running. But safety makes for a boring movie and running is the only thing they do well.
My love of Schu makes it difficult to admit this, but I didn't like Trainwreck.
In a way it's triple-distilled truth, but mostly it feels like an over-interpreted copy of a copy of a copy.
With nobody to root for, BvS:DoJ is just an unconscionably long slugfest simultaneously attempting too much and accomplishing almost nothing.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rauch plays Hope like she lives inside her... Given that the charter is so unlikable, the key to making you root for her are these tiny smiles, small moments when you see through her gnarly exterior. Rauch does that to perfection.
It's occasionally brilliant but never seems comfortable.
As is the way in these Sundance movies, there are moments of beauty, nothing much happens, and at one point somebody runs through the woods.
The film is packed with funny and surprisingly clear explanations of the financial system.
While the first half is full of boat and whale adventures, the movie's second half is just a group of shipwrecked men slowly starving to death. It's boring.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While there's lots to recommend the movie, the silly premise is the only thing I could focus on for the entire 2 hours and 17 minutes -- which is inexcusably long for a movie that is actually just half of a movie.
Any time you watch a "reimagining" of a story in the public domain, you do so at your own peril.
Normally it would annoy me to see a movie that is such a blatant copy, but in this case, Creed feels more like an apology for the mediocre Rocky movies we've endured.
Save your money and just watch YouTube videos of the real thing, which are 100 times more engaging.

Kahil's massive personality compensates for the lack of plotline. It's a portrait of a fascinating man (and his penis) who seems more like a fictional character than a real deli owner. Perhaps a character on Seinfeld.

Filmmaker Giulio Ricciarelli's debut features a gripping story, told through nostalgic shots of men in Mad Men-style suits debating heavy matters in lofty courtrooms, riding pastel Vespas through the countryside or pacing stories-tall archive rooms.
Everybody in the movie sounds exactly the same -- women, men, adults, children, doctors, bartenders and wig makers all talk like they're the same person.
It's a bleak, relentless movie, acted with a steely-eyed intensity that makes it feel important, though certainly not enjoyable.
Fassbender's Jobs oscillates between enthusiasm for his own ideas and outrage that the world can't keep up with him, in exactly the way that people close to the genius described him.
After a couple of days' reflection, while I still would happily recommend the film as one of the best blockbusters I've seen this year, the flaws of the movie became increasingly apparent.
Not to say that Tim Burton's made a bad film, more that this is a missed opportunity.
The Sky Crawlers is Oshii's finest film since 2001's underrated Avalon and his best animé since the original Ghost in the Shell.
In spite of its few shortcomings, the film has much to commend it and its ideas are adeptly fleshed out by an excellent cast.
One of the most assured and impressive feature debuts in recent years.
The lack of information, the strange Jack Kirbyesque details on the walls and the absence of any outside world makes the environment of the film timeless and suitably, subtly existential.

For those seeking the best ninja/samurai action on screen, there are dozens of live action movies either directed by Akira Kurosawa or based on manga by Kazuo Koike that are much better films than Ninja Scroll.
Senn is a gem that will hopefully accrue the cult following it deserves.

The many unique elements that make the film stand out from its peers, including the art on screen, combined with the Emaki-mono presentation, make Belladonna of Sadness a must-see for fans of Japanese animation.
Most of the film is entertaining. The cast is uniformly excellent and the resounding praise aimed at the late Heath Ledger is deserved.
Pushed the boundaries of the depiction of terror on screen and reveals the interest in the language of experimental filmmaking in genre and mainstream cinema of the time.

The lack of any convincing over-arching plot, the muddled use of alternating futures and squashed-together gaggle of wafer-thin characters renders the project a near complete failure when it comes to thrills and entertainment.
The Unborn isn't the worst horror film you'll see in 2009, but the prospect of a sequel (which the film teases at the finale), is probably the biggest fright in the 88 minutes.
Witch Mountain is a full-throttle adventure that features at least half a dozen cracking action sequences, some adult-pleasing comic one-liners.

It sounds like a straight-to-DVD stinker doesn't it? It's pleasantly surprising to report therefore, that Doghouse isn't one of the worst films of the year and is in fact a hilarious, PC brigade-baiting romp.
On paper, The Goods had the potential to be The Next Anchorman, but unfortunately somewhere in the drawing room, someone decided to pursue cheap laughs over something more substantial.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Writer Diablo Cody's willingness to resort to flogging the movie off the back of Fox's cleavage and highly-sexual public profile spoils what could have been an interesting and original addition to the slasher horror genre.
Difficult, odd, kind, obsessive and funny, This Is It finally offers us a very brief glimpse of the real Michael Jackson.
It's a relatively entertaining romp, but it would be surprising if anyone is counting down the days until the third movie.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a better-than-average blockbuster, which sweeps around some large ideas and interesting themes, but never delves for long enough to make this film a true classic.

Wanted never takes itself too seriously and is fully aware of its frailties. This is fast and furious popcorn munching fodder, which doesn't waste time dabbling in meaningful theorising or contemplation.
It's a superb action flick that will have you wide-eyed in awe at its effects; just don't go expecting any kind of literary discussion.

It's 157 minutes long, but immerses its audience with its twists and intricacies as it plays out and considers the logistics and consequences of crime and police corruption, with a plethora of show-stealing performances from the cast.
The action is, of course, electric and Greengrass bookends the movie with the most spectacular chases.
Enchanted still provides a pleasant twist on Walt Disney's traditional output and has enough decent performances from its cast to raise titters and smiles from even the most grumpy movie-goers.
The climax is not nearly as clever as at its set-up, but A Kind of Murder is a smart thriller, one that digs deep into the viewer's mind with difficult questions about guilt and morality.
Considering the similarities to The Graduate, the result feels less like an inspired update and more like a modern-day replica.
Always Shine is a potent statement on gender and femininity, disguised as an avant-garde thriller.
Kicks is an unflinching portrait of inner-city life, both the good and bad.
Director Liza Johnson, working from a script by Joey Sagal, Hanala Sagal and Cary Elwes, deftly captures the historical context of the bizarre meeting for both sides.
A boisterously funny and enjoyable ride that works so well because of its leads.
Skip Rings and rewatch either The Ring or the Japanese original instead.
Cruise is as compelling as ever with charm to spare, and this is a ceaselessly entertaining, sometimes tense romp. Although it doesn't dig much below the surface.
It hardly stirs the heart, at least not as much as you feel it should have done.
This film is a glorious carnival of nonsense.

Everything is respected, but nothing is sacred. It's a sweeping gut-punch. How it deals with our own hopes and dreams for these characters, and how deep it cuts into existential concerns that drive us all - its effects will run around in the mind.
The first hour is particularly noodly, presenting a lonely, isolated young Clapton finding solace in music.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's as infuriating as it is inventive, as it Just... Never... Stops. It is Paris Through the Looking Glass.

Miss Impossible features plenty of clever voice over in which Aurore passes judgement on the adult world and the casual injustices of adolescence. She may be cynical, but her humour keeps her buoyant, loveable, and entirely relatable.
Shaun the Sheep: The Movie, [is] a children's film that's pure joy.
Like a cross between Bring it On and Billy Elliot, there's plenty of dance talent on display in this film.
Like Brie Larson's character in Room, motherhood opens [3000's Nights' protagonist] Layal to her compassion, often letting it guide her even when her anger is overwhelming.
[Jafar] Panahi's Taxi is essential viewing.
Although [My Internship in Canada] is still about a white male member of parliament, it's impressively progressive.
movie_title: My Internship In Canada (Guibord S'en Va-t-en Guerre) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The mechanics of plot leave less time for casual interactions and character development, which leaves the father-daughter relationship under-explored.
The woman may now seem less of an enigma. What made her work great remains a mystery.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While we may feel moved by the music, there's a dark undercurrent in it, too.
It's what an action movie should be at its best; the shots fired are less interesting than the personal struggles of the men in battle.
Watching that journey, checking in along the way at what may seem like small and insignificant moments, has a profound cumulative impact.
By getting very specific about the alienation Rosie has experienced as a Chinese-Iranian Canadian, Ann Marie Fleming gets at something more universal about displacement and diaspora.
[Nasty Baby] is designed to pull you out of your comfort zone, and it does. But its often half-baked ideas mean it's more repulsive than thought-provoking.
If the Bang Gang springs from loneliness and insecurity, why don't we see moments of vulnerability between any of the characters?
Chloé Zhao's directorial debut Songs My Brothers Taught Me is a quiet, sensitive indigenous coming-of-age story set as high school graduation nears on the Pine Ridge Reserve.
Come for a trip to gorgeous vistas in faraway lands; stay for the character drama
The verse, in [Justin] Kurzel's hands, is barely even identifiable as poetry. But what is Shakespeare without the unforgettable language?
45 Years is devastating, thought-provoking, and romantic.
God's Own Country is a swoon-worthy romance.
The compassion with which the actors deliver and respond to these revelations is nuanced and emotional.
Danish screenwriter Rasmus Heisterberg makes a strong directorial debut with In the Blood, which takes inspiration from the films of Joachim Trier.
Nashawati crafts a nail-biting psychological thriller almost entirely through sound design, colour scheme, editing, and her lead's utterly convincing performance.
The hyper-realistic performances and strong screenplay make the punishing runtime, designed to make you feel the exhaustion of family gatherings, worth pushing through.
This Changes Everything is the rarest breed of activist documentary: one that doesn't preach.
Spending a couple of hours with impeccably dressed (even for the Bond franchise), amazingly talented, and utterly gorgeous stars doing stagy acting is a fine way to pass an evening.
Every time you think there's a limit to their stupidity and bad decisions, you're proven wrong. It gets worse.
The high-tech visualizations and the beautiful images are what makes Racing Extinction a must-see. It's awe-inspiring and vital.
Set entirely in their apartment, Lafosse finds meaning in the space and how they inhabit it
Because [The End of the Tour] is a film about language and about two men in dialogue, it's greatness could not have been achieved without the performances.
The Diary of a Teenage Girl is all about blurred lines and confusing emotions.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film tried my patience even as I marveled at its aesthetic: pretty things just aren't enough.
[In the Shadow of Women is] a trifle, and an often enjoyable one if you don't think too much about how the humour relies on outdated stereotypes, but it's easily forgotten and missed.
I've seen more eroticism in far less graphic films.
The real star of the film may be cinematographer Roger Deakins, whose work here is both breathtaking and purposeful, a huge part of why [Sicario] remains thrilling even as its plot loses steam.
Without the reuniting Adventureland pair Kristen Stewart and Jesse Eisenberg as the leads, the film could have easily been just another dumb stoner action film with moderate laughs.
[Grandma] is an entirely unimaginatively directed melange of indie aesthetic cliches.
It's a film grounded in place that never quite finds its footing in plot.
Unfortunately, the film never hits the emotional highs or lows it's aiming for, and the comedy is too sedate to be enough to carry the film: it's more likely to induce silent chuckles than laughs.
It's a bit of a shaggy dog tale and quite a disappointment from this talented director.
Here's hoping The Ninth Floor will galvanize much needed discussion while commemorating this crucial, oft-forgotten chapter in [Canadian] history.
There are more interesting ways to explore how afraid we are of girl sexuality and how god-fearing Christians can use their faith for destruction.
But [The Rainbow Kid] is not a light and gooey family film about how a boy with a disability teaches the able-bodied about life. It's something much smarter, much darker, and much more necessary.

Whether it's the breath of a partner lying in bed next to you or the thump of a tight hug, [Anne] Émond has a gift for making you feel like you're there in that moment, where being near someone is a form of comfort.
Through terrific nature photography from Renan Ozturk, Hugh Miller, and Ken Sauls, [Jennifer] Peedom has captured anew the wonder of Everest.
With Every Thing Will Be Fine, [Wim] Wenders has proved that using 3D need not be confined to documentary filmmaking, but that it can be absolutely vital to drama.
There's a fine line between close friendships and toxic ones, and for teenage girls, there's perhaps an even finer one between sapphic love and best friends.
If you think that theatre has nothing to do with your cinephilic tendencies, Office is easy proof that the masters of cinema tend to borrow from the stage, to often exquisite effect.
Shooting in Scope, an aspect ratio more frequently associated with vast landscapes, [director Magnus] von Horn often confines the action to a fraction of the frame.
The Martian would be a great engineering recruitment film - if it ever mentioned the word 'engineering.'

[Hanna] Sköld gets good performances out of her actors while proving herself adept at telling a feminist story of multiple generations, cycles of abuse in a family, and emancipation in more than one medium.
[Actress] Manal Issa is an exquisite discovery in Parisienne.
Ultimately, the film's ambitions of inclusivity, both in its story and its casting, are more admirable than the execution.
[Girl Unbound] clumsily addresses gender norms and trans identities.
These actors could have tackled much more difficult terrain, with grace and intelligence, had Davies and Davis given them the opportunity.
Mary's coming out is about not just coming to terms with her sexuality, but also with who she is and who she wants around her.
Although the film delights in the mundane, make no mistake: the film is a fantasy. And for a couple of hours, it's a blissful, peaceful world to live in, where you glimpse excitement from a distance.
Michael Almereyda's screen adaptation of the Pulitzer-Prize nominated play Marjorie Prime never sheds its theatrical origins and fails to find new insights as a film.

Through humour, gorgeous visuals, and 13 different characters all played by Cate Blanchett, Manifesto interrogates the purpose and sincerity of manifestos... It is a rousing call for original thought.

Guadagnino's new film is also his sweetest, calmest, and loveliest. It sneaks up on you. Throughout, Guadagnino captures what first love feels like, in all its fumbling, awkward, confusing, terrifying, joyous glory.
An exclusionary narrative that refuses to reckon with the large-scale problems the film's protagonists are ultimately fighting against.
DuVernay has an impressive knack for finding exhilarating but measured rhythms, keeping your adrenaline pumping without ever exhausting you.
Andrew Neel's Goat is an excellent showcase for up-and-coming star Ben Schnetzer, whose strong performance hints at the better film it could have been.
Dench gives an unwavering performance as a woman who is a survivor, with an impressive ability to forgive even those that don't deserve it.
The strength of Katniss Everdeen as a character is what makes The Hunger Games: Catching Fire so compelling.
The film is as much about feeling connected to someone as it is about feeling disconnected. Watching Adele dance in different situations lets us gauge her comfort level.
As Ginsberg, Radcliffe shows great vulnerability, as a man in love who can't express it, and a passionate and intelligent one still prone to naivety.
This thought-provoking and emotionally volatile story is anchored by three world-class performances.
